section_body:
Main article: [Symptoms of COVID-19](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symptoms_of_COVID-19 "Symptoms of COVID-19")

[![Image 28](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Symptoms_of_coronavirus_disease_2019_4.0.svg/500px-Symptoms_of_coronavirus_disease_2019_4.0.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Symptoms_of_coronavirus_disease_2019_4.0.svg)

[Symptoms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signs_and_symptoms "Signs and symptoms") of COVID-19

Symptoms of COVID-19 are variable, ranging from mild symptoms to severe illness.[[103]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-CDC2020Sym-104)[[104]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Grant_et_al_2020-105) Common symptoms include headache, [loss of smell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anosmia "Anosmia") and [taste](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ageusia "Ageusia"), [nasal congestion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nasal_obstruction "Nasal obstruction") and [runny nose](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhinorrhea "Rhinorrhea"), cough, [muscle pain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muscle_pain "Muscle pain"), [sore throat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sore_throat "Sore throat"), fever, [diarrhoea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diarrhea "Diarrhea"), and [breathing difficulties](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Breathing_difficulties "Breathing difficulties").[[103]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-CDC2020Sym-104) People with the same infection may have different symptoms, and their symptoms may change over time. Three common clusters of symptoms have been identified: one respiratory symptom cluster with cough, [sputum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sputum "Sputum"), shortness of breath, and fever; a musculoskeletal symptom cluster with muscle and joint pain, headache, and fatigue; a cluster of digestive symptoms with abdominal pain, vomiting, and diarrhoea.[[105]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-ECDC-106) In people without prior ear, nose, and throat disorders, [loss of taste](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypogeusia "Hypogeusia") combined with [loss of smell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyposmia "Hyposmia") is associated with [COVID-19](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19 "COVID-19") and is reported in as many as 88% of cases.[[106]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Krishnan-107)[[107]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-108)[[108]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-pmid32483687-109)

triples.sentence: In people without prior ear, nose, and throat disorders, [loss of taste](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypogeusia "Hypogeusia") combined with [loss of smell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyposmia "Hyposmia") is associated with [COVID-19](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19 "COVID-19") and is reported in as many as 88% of cases.[[106]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Krishnan-107)[[107]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-108)[[108]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-pmid32483687-109)
triples.statement: For individuals without pre-existing ear, nose, and throat conditions, the combined loss of taste and smell is associated with COVID-19 and is reported in up to 88% of cases.

section_body:
Main article: [Transmission of COVID-19](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transmission_of_COVID-19 "Transmission of COVID-19")

The disease is mainly transmitted via the respiratory route when people inhale droplets and small airborne particles (that form an [aerosol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aerosol "Aerosol")) that infected people exhale as they breathe, talk, cough, sneeze, or sing.[[109]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Wang_2021-110)[[110]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-auto-111)[[111]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AR2021-112)[[112]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-auto1-113) Infected people are more likely to transmit COVID-19 when they are physically close to other non-infected individuals. However, infection can occur over longer distances, particularly indoors.[[109]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Wang_2021-110)[[113]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Miller_2021-114)

triples.sentence: The disease is mainly transmitted via the respiratory route when people inhale droplets and small airborne particles (that form an [aerosol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aerosol "Aerosol")) that infected people exhale as they breathe, talk, cough, sneeze, or sing.[[109]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Wang_2021-110)[[110]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-auto-111)[[111]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AR2021-112)[[112]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-auto1-113)
triples.statement: The disease is primarily transmitted through the respiratory route when individuals inhale droplets and small airborne particles exhaled by infected people during activities like breathing, talking, coughing, sneezing, or singing.

triples.sentence: However, infection can occur over longer distances, particularly indoors.[[109]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Wang_2021-110)[[113]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Miller_2021-114)
triples.statement: Infection can happen over longer distances, especially in indoor settings.

section_body:
Main article: [COVID-19 §Diagnosis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19#Diagnosis "COVID-19")

[![Image 30](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/2020Sept26-BioFire-Waldron-HR.jpg/250px-2020Sept26-BioFire-Waldron-HR.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:2020Sept26-BioFire-Waldron-HR.jpg)

A nurse at [McMurdo Station](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/McMurdo_Station "McMurdo Station") sets up the polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing equipment, in September 2020

The standard method of testing for presence of SARS-CoV-2 is a [nucleic acid test](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nucleic_acid_test "Nucleic acid test"),[[117]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200130cdc-118) which detects the presence of viral RNA fragments.[[118]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-WHO_InterimGuidance-119) As these tests detect RNA but not infectious virus, its "ability to determine duration of infectivity of patients is limited".[[119]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-2k0iS-120) The test is typically done on respiratory samples obtained by a [nasopharyngeal swab](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nasopharyngeal_swab "Nasopharyngeal swab"); however, a nasal swab or sputum sample may also be used.[[120]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-CDC2020Testing-121)[[121]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200129cdc-122) The WHO has published several testing protocols for the disease.[[122]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-123)

triples.sentence: The test is typically done on respiratory samples obtained by a [nasopharyngeal swab](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nasopharyngeal_swab "Nasopharyngeal swab"); however, a nasal swab or sputum sample may also be used.[[120]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-CDC2020Testing-121)[[121]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200129cdc-122)
triples.statement: The test is typically performed on respiratory samples from a nasopharyngeal swab, though a nasal swab or sputum sample can also be used.

section_body:
Main article: [COVID-19 vaccine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_vaccine "COVID-19 vaccine")

See also: [History of COVID-19 vaccine development](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_COVID-19_vaccine_development "History of COVID-19 vaccine development") and [Deployment of COVID-19 vaccines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deployment_of_COVID-19_vaccines "Deployment of COVID-19 vaccines")

[![Image 32](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Elderly_Slovak_woman_receiving_her_third_Covid-19_vaccine_02.jpg/250px-Elderly_Slovak_woman_receiving_her_third_Covid-19_vaccine_02.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Elderly_Slovak_woman_receiving_her_third_Covid-19_vaccine_02.jpg)

An elderly woman receiving a COVID-19 vaccination in [Slovakia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slovakia "Slovakia")

A COVID-19 [vaccine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vaccine "Vaccine") is intended to provide [acquired immunity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acquired_immunity "Acquired immunity") against [severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Severe_acute_respiratory_syndrome_coronavirus_2 "Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2") (SARS‑CoV‑2), the virus that causes coronavirus disease 2019 ([COVID-19](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19 "COVID-19")). Prior to the COVID-19 pandemic, an established body of knowledge existed about the structure and function of [coronaviruses](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coronavirus "Coronavirus") causing diseases like [severe acute respiratory syndrome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Severe_acute_respiratory_syndrome "Severe acute respiratory syndrome") (SARS) and [Middle East respiratory syndrome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Middle_East_respiratory_syndrome "Middle East respiratory syndrome") (MERS). This knowledge accelerated the development of various [vaccine platforms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vaccine_platform "Vaccine platform") during early 2020.[[128]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-pmid33341119-129) The initial focus of SARS-CoV-2 vaccines was on preventing symptomatic and severe illness.[[129]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-130) The COVID-19 vaccines are widely credited for their role in reducing the severity and death caused by COVID-19.[[130]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-131)[[131]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-132)

As of March 2023, more than 5.5 billion people had received one or more doses[[132]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-133) (11.8 billion in total) in over 197 countries. The Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine was the most widely used.[[133]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-134) According to a June 2022 study, COVID-19 vaccines prevented an additional 14.4 million to 19.8 million deaths in 185 countries and territories from 8 December 2020 to 8 December 2021.[[134]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-135)[[135]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-136)

On 8 November 2022, the first recombinant protein-based COVID-19 vaccine (Novavax's booster [Nuvaxovid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuvaxovid "Nuvaxovid")) was authorised for use in adults in the United Kingdom. It has subsequently received endorsement/authorisation from the WHO, US, European Union, and Australia.[[136]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-137)[[137]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-138)

On 12 November 2022, the WHO released its Global Vaccine Market Report. The report indicated that "inequitable distribution is not unique to COVID-19 vaccines"; countries that are not economically strong struggle to obtain vaccines.[[138]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-139)

On 14 November 2022, the first inhalable vaccine was introduced, developed by Chinese biopharmaceutical company [CanSino Biologics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CanSino_Biologics#COVID-19_vaccine_development "CanSino Biologics"), in the city of Shanghai, China.[[139]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-140)

triples.sentence: As of March 2023, more than 5.5 billion people had received one or more doses[[132]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-133) (11.8 billion in total) in over 197 countries.
triples.statement: As of March 2023, more than 5.5 billion people had received one or more vaccine doses (11.8 billion total) in over 197 countries.

triples.sentence: The Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine was the most widely used.[[133]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-134)
triples.statement: The Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine was the most widely used.

triples.sentence: It has subsequently received endorsement/authorisation from the WHO, US, European Union, and Australia.[[136]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-137)[[137]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-138)
triples.statement: The Nuvaxovid vaccine has subsequently received endorsement or authorization from the WHO, US, European Union, and Australia.

section_body:
Main article: [Treatment and management of COVID-19](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Treatment_and_management_of_COVID-19 "Treatment and management of COVID-19")

[![Image 33](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Respiradores_da_USP_utilizados_do_Incor_%2850119127303%29.jpg/250px-Respiradores_da_USP_utilizados_do_Incor_%2850119127303%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Respiradores_da_USP_utilizados_do_Incor_(50119127303).jpg)

A critically ill patient receiving invasive ventilation in the intensive care unit of the [Heart Institute, University of São Paulo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heart_Institute,_University_of_S%C3%A3o_Paulo "Heart Institute, University of São Paulo") in July 2020. Due to a shortage of mechanical ventilators, a [bridge ventilator](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Resuscitator "Resuscitator") is being used to automatically actuate a [bag valve mask](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bag_valve_mask "Bag valve mask")

For the first two years of the pandemic, no specific and effective treatment or cure was available.[[140]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-BMJLivingReview-141)[[141]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-cdcmuseum-142) In 2021, the European Medicines Agency's (EMA) Committee for Medicinal Products for Human Use (CHMP) approved the oral antiviral [protease inhibitor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Protease_inhibitor_(pharmacology) "Protease inhibitor (pharmacology)"), [Paxlovid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paxlovid "Paxlovid") (nirmatrelvir plus the HIV antiviral [ritonavir](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ritonavir "Ritonavir")), to treat adult patients.[[142]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-143) FDA later gave it an EUA.[[143]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-144)

Most cases of COVID-19 are mild. In these, supportive care includes medication such as [paracetamol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paracetamol "Paracetamol") or [NSAIDs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NSAID "NSAID") to relieve symptoms (fever,[[144]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-145) body aches, cough), adequate intake of oral fluids and rest.[[141]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-cdcmuseum-142)[[145]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-146) Good personal hygiene and a [healthy diet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Healthy_diet "Healthy diet") are also recommended.[[146]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-147)

[Supportive care](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supportive_care "Supportive care") in severe cases includes treatment to [relieve symptoms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symptomatic_treatment "Symptomatic treatment"), [fluid therapy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fluid_replacement "Fluid replacement"), [oxygen support](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oxygen_support "Oxygen support") and [prone positioning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prone_positioning "Prone positioning"), and medications or devices to support other affected vital organs.[[147]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-148) More severe cases may need treatment in hospital. In those with low oxygen levels, use of the glucocorticoid [dexamethasone](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dexamethasone "Dexamethasone") is recommended to reduce mortality.[[148]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-149)[Noninvasive ventilation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noninvasive_ventilation "Noninvasive ventilation") and, ultimately, admission to an [intensive care unit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intensive_care_unit "Intensive care unit") for [mechanical ventilation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mechanical_ventilation "Mechanical ventilation") may be required to support breathing.[[149]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-NIHGuidelines2020-150)[Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extracorporeal_membrane_oxygenation "Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation") (ECMO) has been used to address the issue of respiratory failure.[[150]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Guan_Ni_Hu_Liang_p.-151)[[151]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Henry_2020_p.-152)

Existing drugs such as [hydroxychloroquine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydroxychloroquine "Hydroxychloroquine"), [lopinavir/ritonavir](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lopinavir/ritonavir "Lopinavir/ritonavir"), and [ivermectin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ivermectin "Ivermectin") are not recommended by US or European health authorities, as there is no good evidence they have any useful effect.[[140]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-BMJLivingReview-141)[[152]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Kim_Read_Fauci_p=2149-153)[[153]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-NIHGuidelinesTherapeuticManagement-154) The antiviral [remdesivir](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Remdesivir "Remdesivir") is available in the US, Canada, Australia, and several other countries, with varying restrictions; however, it is not recommended for use with mechanical ventilation, and is discouraged altogether by the WHO,[[154]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Hsu_p=m4457-155) due to limited evidence of its efficacy.[[140]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-BMJLivingReview-141)

triples.sentence: FDA later gave it an EUA.[[143]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-144)
triples.statement: The FDA later granted Paxlovid an Emergency Use Authorization (EUA).

triples.sentence: In these, supportive care includes medication such as [paracetamol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paracetamol "Paracetamol") or [NSAIDs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NSAID "NSAID") to relieve symptoms (fever,[[144]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-145) body aches, cough), adequate intake of oral fluids and rest.[[141]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-cdcmuseum-142)[[145]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-146)
triples.statement: For mild cases, supportive care includes medications like paracetamol or NSAIDs for symptom relief, along with fluid intake and rest.

triples.sentence: [Noninvasive ventilation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noninvasive_ventilation "Noninvasive ventilation") and, ultimately, admission to an [intensive care unit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intensive_care_unit "Intensive care unit") for [mechanical ventilation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mechanical_ventilation "Mechanical ventilation") may be required to support breathing.[[149]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-NIHGuidelines2020-150)
triples.statement: To support breathing, noninvasive ventilation or admission to an intensive care unit for mechanical ventilation may be required.

triples.sentence: [Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extracorporeal_membrane_oxygenation "Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation") (ECMO) has been used to address the issue of respiratory failure.[[150]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Guan_Ni_Hu_Liang_p.-151)[[151]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Henry_2020_p.-152)
triples.statement: Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) has been used to treat respiratory failure.

triples.sentence: Existing drugs such as [hydroxychloroquine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydroxychloroquine "Hydroxychloroquine"), [lopinavir/ritonavir](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lopinavir/ritonavir "Lopinavir/ritonavir"), and [ivermectin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ivermectin "Ivermectin") are not recommended by US or European health authorities, as there is no good evidence they have any useful effect.[[140]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-BMJLivingReview-141)[[152]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Kim_Read_Fauci_p=2149-153)[[153]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-NIHGuidelinesTherapeuticManagement-154)
triples.statement: US and European health authorities do not recommend drugs such as hydroxychloroquine, lopinavir/ritonavir, and ivermectin, as there is no good evidence of their effectiveness.

triples.sentence: The antiviral [remdesivir](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Remdesivir "Remdesivir") is available in the US, Canada, Australia, and several other countries, with varying restrictions; however, it is not recommended for use with mechanical ventilation, and is discouraged altogether by the WHO,[[154]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Hsu_p=m4457-155) due to limited evidence of its efficacy.[[140]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-BMJLivingReview-141)
triples.statement: Although available in several countries, the antiviral remdesivir is not recommended for patients on mechanical ventilation and is discouraged by the WHO due to limited evidence of efficacy.

section_body:
Further information: [COVID-19 §Prognosis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19#Prognosis "COVID-19"), and [Long COVID](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Long_COVID "Long COVID")

The severity of COVID-19 varies. It may take a mild course with few or no symptoms, resembling other common upper respiratory diseases such as the [common cold](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Common_cold "Common cold"). In 3–4% of cases (7.4% for those over age 65) symptoms are severe enough to cause hospitalisation.[[155]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-pmid33087398-156) Mild cases typically recover within two weeks, while those with severe or critical diseases may take three to six weeks to recover. Among those who have died, the time from symptom onset to death has ranged from two to eight weeks. Prolonged [prothrombin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prothrombin "Prothrombin") time and elevated [C-reactive protein](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/C-reactive_protein "C-reactive protein") levels on admission to the hospital are associated with severe course of COVID-19 and with a transfer to [intensive care units](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intensive_care_unit "Intensive care unit") (ICU).[[156]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-157)[[157]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-158)

Between 5% and 50% of COVID-19 patients experience [long COVID](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Long_COVID "Long COVID"),[[158]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-159) a condition characterised by long-term [consequences](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sequela "Sequela") persisting after the typical convalescence period of the disease.[[159]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-160)[[160]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-161) The most commonly reported clinical presentations are [fatigue](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fatigue "Fatigue") and memory problems, as well as [malaise](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malaise "Malaise"), headaches, [shortness of breath](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shortness_of_breath "Shortness of breath"), loss of smell, [muscle weakness](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muscle_weakness "Muscle weakness"), low fever and [cognitive dysfunction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_dysfunction "Cognitive dysfunction").[[161]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-ref1-162)[[162]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-163)[[163]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-164)[[164]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-165)

triples.sentence: In 3–4% of cases (7.4% for those over age 65) symptoms are severe enough to cause hospitalisation.[[155]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-pmid33087398-156)
triples.statement: In 3–4% of COVID-19 cases, and 7.4% for those over age 65, symptoms are severe enough to require hospitalization.

triples.sentence: The most commonly reported clinical presentations are [fatigue](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fatigue "Fatigue") and memory problems, as well as [malaise](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malaise "Malaise"), headaches, [shortness of breath](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shortness_of_breath "Shortness of breath"), loss of smell, [muscle weakness](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muscle_weakness "Muscle weakness"), low fever and [cognitive dysfunction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_dysfunction "Cognitive dysfunction").[[161]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-ref1-162)[[162]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-163)[[163]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-164)[[164]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-165)
triples.statement: The most common clinical presentations of long COVID include fatigue, memory problems, malaise, headaches, shortness of breath, loss of smell, muscle weakness, low fever, and cognitive dysfunction.

section_body:
Main article: [Public health mitigation of COVID-19](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_health_mitigation_of_COVID-19 "Public health mitigation of COVID-19")

[![Image 34](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/20200410_Flatten_the_curve%2C_raise_the_line_-_pandemic_%28English%29.gif/500px-20200410_Flatten_the_curve%2C_raise_the_line_-_pandemic_%28English%29.gif)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:20200410_Flatten_the_curve,_raise_the_line_-_pandemic_(English).gif)

Goals of mitigation include delaying and reducing peak burden on healthcare (_[flattening the curve](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flattening\_the\_curve "Flattening the curve")_) and lessening overall cases and health impact.[[165]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Lancet2020Flatten-166)[[166]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-RnW59-167) Moreover, progressively greater increases in healthcare capacity (_[raising the line](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raising\_the\_line "Raising the line")_) such as by increasing bed count, personnel, and equipment, help to meet increased demand[[167]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Vox_20200407-168)

Many countries attempted to slow or stop the spread of COVID-19 by recommending, mandating or prohibiting behaviour changes, while others relied primarily on providing information. Measures ranged from public advisories to stringent lockdowns. Outbreak control strategies are divided into elimination and mitigation. Experts differentiate between elimination strategies (known as "[zero-COVID](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zero-COVID "Zero-COVID")") that aim to completely stop the spread of the virus within the community,[[168]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Barcelona-169) and mitigation strategies (commonly known as "[flattening the curve](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flattening_the_curve "Flattening the curve")") that attempt to lessen the effects of the virus on society, but which still tolerate some level of transmission within the community.[[169]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Livermore-170) These initial strategies can be pursued sequentially or simultaneously during the [acquired immunity phase](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acquired_immunity "Acquired immunity") through natural and [vaccine-induced immunity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_vaccine "COVID-19 vaccine").[[170]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Bhopal2020-171)

_Nature_ reported in 2021 that 90% of researchers who responded to a survey "think that the coronavirus will become [endemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Endemic_(epidemiology) "Endemic (epidemiology)")".[[171]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-172)

triples.sentence: _Nature_ reported in 2021 that 90% of researchers who responded to a survey "think that the coronavirus will become [endemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Endemic_(epidemiology) "Endemic (epidemiology)")".[[171]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-172)
triples.statement: In 2021, Nature reported that 90% of researchers in a survey believe the coronavirus will become endemic.

section_body:
Further information: [Zero-COVID](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zero-COVID "Zero-COVID")

Containment is undertaken to stop an outbreak from spreading into the general population. Infected individuals are isolated while they are infectious. The people they have interacted with are contacted and isolated for long enough to ensure that they are either not infected or no longer contagious. Screening is the starting point for containment. Screening is done by checking for symptoms to identify infected individuals, who can then be isolated or offered treatment.[[172]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-f4SpW-173) The zero-COVID strategy involves using public health measures such as [contact tracing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contact_tracing "Contact tracing"), [mass testing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_testing "COVID-19 testing"), [border quarantine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Travel_during_the_COVID-19_pandemic "Travel during the COVID-19 pandemic"), [lockdowns](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_lockdowns "COVID-19 lockdowns"), and [mitigation software](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Use_and_development_of_software_for_COVID-19_pandemic_mitigation "Use and development of software for COVID-19 pandemic mitigation") to stop [community transmission](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transmission_of_COVID-19 "Transmission of COVID-19") of COVID-19 as soon as it is detected, with the goal of getting the area back to zero detected infections and resuming normal economic and social activities.[[168]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Barcelona-169)[[173]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Lancet-Li-2020-174) Successful containment or suppression reduces [Rt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Basic_reproduction_number#Effective_reproduction_number "Basic reproduction number") to less than 1.[[174]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-ImpCollege16mar2020-175)

triples.sentence: Screening is done by checking for symptoms to identify infected individuals, who can then be isolated or offered treatment.[[172]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-f4SpW-173)
triples.statement: Screening involves checking for symptoms to find infected individuals who can then be isolated or treated.

triples.sentence: Successful containment or suppression reduces [Rt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Basic_reproduction_number#Effective_reproduction_number "Basic reproduction number") to less than 1.[[174]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-ImpCollege16mar2020-175)
triples.statement: Successful containment or suppression lowers the effective reproduction number (Rt) to less than 1.

section_body:
Further information: [Flattening the curve](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flattening_the_curve "Flattening the curve")

Should containment fail, efforts focus on mitigation: measures taken to slow the spread and limit its effects on the healthcare system and society. Successful mitigation delays and decreases the epidemic peak, known as "flattening the [epidemic curve](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epidemic_curve "Epidemic curve")".[[165]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Lancet2020Flatten-166) This decreases the risk of overwhelming health services and provides more time for developing vaccines and treatments.[[165]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Lancet2020Flatten-166) Individual behaviour changed in many jurisdictions. Many people worked from home instead of at their traditional workplaces.[[175]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-176)

triples.sentence: Many people worked from home instead of at their traditional workplaces.[[175]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-176)
triples.statement: Many people worked from home instead of their traditional workplaces.

section_body:
[![Image 35](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/04.02_%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1%E8%A6%96%E5%AF%9F%E3%80%8C%E4%B8%AD%E5%A4%AE%E6%B5%81%E8%A1%8C%E7%96%AB%E6%83%85%E6%8C%87%E6%8F%AE%E4%B8%AD%E5%BF%83%E3%80%8D_49726568957_66543b616e_o.jpg/250px-04.02_%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1%E8%A6%96%E5%AF%9F%E3%80%8C%E4%B8%AD%E5%A4%AE%E6%B5%81%E8%A1%8C%E7%96%AB%E6%83%85%E6%8C%87%E6%8F%AE%E4%B8%AD%E5%BF%83%E3%80%8D_49726568957_66543b616e_o.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:04.02_%E7%B8%BD%E7%B5%B1%E8%A6%96%E5%AF%9F%E3%80%8C%E4%B8%AD%E5%A4%AE%E6%B5%81%E8%A1%8C%E7%96%AB%E6%83%85%E6%8C%87%E6%8F%AE%E4%B8%AD%E5%BF%83%E3%80%8D_49726568957_66543b616e_o.jpg)

The CDC and WHO advise that masks (such as worn here by Taiwanese president [Tsai Ing-wen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tsai_Ing-wen "Tsai Ing-wen")) reduce the spread of SARS-CoV-2

[Non-pharmaceutical interventions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-pharmaceutical_intervention "Non-pharmaceutical intervention") that may reduce spread include personal actions such as wearing [face masks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Face_masks_during_the_COVID-19_pandemic "Face masks during the COVID-19 pandemic"), self-quarantine, and [hand hygiene](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hand_washing "Hand washing"); community measures aimed at reducing interpersonal contacts such as closing workplaces and schools and cancelling large gatherings; community engagement to encourage acceptance and participation in such interventions; as well as environmental measures such as surface cleaning.[[176]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-community_mitigation-177)

triples.sentence: [Non-pharmaceutical interventions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-pharmaceutical_intervention "Non-pharmaceutical intervention") that may reduce spread include personal actions such as wearing [face masks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Face_masks_during_the_COVID-19_pandemic "Face masks during the COVID-19 pandemic"), self-quarantine, and [hand hygiene](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hand_washing "Hand washing"); community measures aimed at reducing interpersonal contacts such as closing workplaces and schools and cancelling large gatherings; community engagement to encourage acceptance and participation in such interventions; as well as environmental measures such as surface cleaning.[[176]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-community_mitigation-177)
triples.statement: Non-pharmaceutical interventions that may reduce spread include personal actions (like wearing face masks, self-quarantine, and hand hygiene), community measures (like closing workplaces and schools), community engagement, and environmental measures (like surface cleaning).

section_body:
Further information: [Flattening the curve](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flattening_the_curve "Flattening the curve"), [list of countries by hospital beds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_hospital_beds "List of countries by hospital beds"), and [Shortages related to the COVID-19 pandemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shortages_related_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic "Shortages related to the COVID-19 pandemic")

WHO described increasing capacity and adapting healthcare as a fundamental mitigation.[[185]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-WHOEuropeResponse-186) The ECDC and WHO's European regional office issued guidelines for hospitals and [primary healthcare](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Primary_health_care "Primary health care") services for shifting resources at multiple levels, including focusing laboratory services towards testing, cancelling elective procedures, separating and isolating patients, and increasing [intensive care](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intensive_care_unit "Intensive care unit") capabilities by training personnel and increasing [ventilators](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ventilator "Ventilator") and beds.[[185]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-WHOEuropeResponse-186)[[186]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-ECDCresponse-187) The pandemic drove widespread adoption of [telehealth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telehealth "Telehealth").[[187]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-188)

triples.sentence: WHO described increasing capacity and adapting healthcare as a fundamental mitigation.[[185]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-WHOEuropeResponse-186)
triples.statement: The WHO described increasing capacity and adapting healthcare as a fundamental mitigation strategy.

triples.sentence: The ECDC and WHO's European regional office issued guidelines for hospitals and [primary healthcare](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Primary_health_care "Primary health care") services for shifting resources at multiple levels, including focusing laboratory services towards testing, cancelling elective procedures, separating and isolating patients, and increasing [intensive care](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intensive_care_unit "Intensive care unit") capabilities by training personnel and increasing [ventilators](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ventilator "Ventilator") and beds.[[185]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-WHOEuropeResponse-186)[[186]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-ECDCresponse-187)
triples.statement: The ECDC and WHO's European regional office issued guidelines for hospitals and primary healthcare services to shift resources by focusing on testing, canceling elective procedures, isolating patients, and increasing intensive care capabilities.

triples.sentence: The pandemic drove widespread adoption of [telehealth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telehealth "Telehealth").[[187]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-188)
triples.statement: The pandemic drove widespread adoption of telehealth.

section_body: In July 2021, several experts expressed concern that achieving [herd immunity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herd_immunity "Herd immunity") may not be possible because Delta can transmit among vaccinated individuals.[[192]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-:1-193) CDC published data showing that vaccinated people could transmit Delta, something officials believed was less likely with other variants. Consequently, WHO and CDC encouraged vaccinated people to continue with non-pharmaceutical interventions such as masking, social distancing, and quarantining if exposed.[[193]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-:2-194)

triples.sentence: In July 2021, several experts expressed concern that achieving [herd immunity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herd_immunity "Herd immunity") may not be possible because Delta can transmit among vaccinated individuals.[[192]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-:1-193)
triples.statement: In July 2021, experts expressed concern that achieving herd immunity might not be possible because the Delta variant can be transmitted among vaccinated individuals.

triples.sentence: Consequently, WHO and CDC encouraged vaccinated people to continue with non-pharmaceutical interventions such as masking, social distancing, and quarantining if exposed.[[193]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-:2-194)
triples.statement: The WHO and CDC encouraged vaccinated people to continue with non-pharmaceutical interventions such as masking, social distancing, and quarantining if exposed.

section_body:
Main article: [Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in 2019](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_2019 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in 2019")

The [outbreak](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outbreak "Outbreak") was discovered in Wuhan in November 2019. It is possible that human-to-human transmission was happening before the discovery.[[38]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Hu2020natureReviews-38)[[39]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Graham2020immunity-39) Based on a retrospective analysis starting from December 2019, the number of cases in Hubei gradually increased, reaching 60 by 20 December and at least 266 by 31 December.[[194]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-original_report-195) A [pneumonia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pneumonia "Pneumonia") cluster was observed on 26 December and treated by Chinese pulmonologist [Zhang Jixian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zhang_Jixian "Zhang Jixian"). She informed the Wuhan Jianghan CDC on 27 December.[[195]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-D54YB-196) After analysing pneumonia patient samples, a genetic sequencing company named Vision Medicals reported the discovery of a [novel coronavirus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novel_coronavirus "Novel coronavirus") to the [China CDC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_Center_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention "Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention") (CCDC) on 28 December.[[196]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AP_OR-197)[[197]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-caixintrace-198) Two days later, a test report from CapitalBio Medlab addressed to the [Wuhan Central Hospital](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_Hospital_of_Wuhan "Central Hospital of Wuhan") reported an erroneous positive result for [SARS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SARS "SARS"), causing doctors there to alert authorities. Eight of those doctors, including ophthalmologist [Li Wenliang](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Li_Wenliang "Li Wenliang") (1985–2020), were detained by police on 3 January for "spreading false rumours".[[198]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-siStf-199) That evening, Wuhan Municipal Health Commission (WMHC) issued a notice about "the treatment of pneumonia of unknown cause".[[199]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-promedmail6864153-200) The next day, WMHC made the announcement public, confirming 27 cases[[200]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AutoDW-69-201)[[201]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AutoDW-68-202)—enough to trigger an investigation.[[202]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-bbc50984025-203) On 31 December, the WHO office in China was notified about the cluster of unknown pneumonia cases[[21]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-WHO_report-21)[[200]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AutoDW-69-201) and immediately launched an investigation.[[202]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-bbc50984025-203)

Official Chinese sources claimed that the early cases were mostly linked to the Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market, which also sold live animals.[[203]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-characteristicsZH-204) In May 2020, CCDC director George Gao initially ruled out the market as a possible origin, as animal samples collected there had tested negative.[[204]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-ALmAQ-205)

triples.statement: The following day, the WMHC publicly announced 27 cases, which was sufficient to trigger an investigation.

triples.statement: Official Chinese sources claimed that early cases were mostly linked to the Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market, which also sold live animals.

section_body:
Timelines of the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020 by month: [January](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_January_2020 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in January 2020"), [February](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_February_2020 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in February 2020"), [March](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_March_2020 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in March 2020"), [April](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_April_2020 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in April 2020"), [May](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_May_2020 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in May 2020"), [June](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_June_2020 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in June 2020"), [July](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_July_2020 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in July 2020"), [August](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_August_2020 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in August 2020"), [September](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_September_2020 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in September 2020"), [October](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_October_2020 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in October 2020"), [November](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_November_2020 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in November 2020"), [December](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_December_2020 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in December 2020")

[![Image 37](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/COVID-19_highway_sign_in_Toronto%2C_March_2020.jpg/250px-COVID-19_highway_sign_in_Toronto%2C_March_2020.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:COVID-19_highway_sign_in_Toronto,_March_2020.jpg)

A highway sign discouraging travel in [Toronto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toronto "Toronto"), March 2020

On 11 January, WHO was notified by the Chinese National Health Commission that the outbreak was associated with exposures in the market, and that China had identified a new type of coronavirus, which it isolated on 7 January.[[21]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-WHO_report-21)

Initially, the number of cases doubled approximately every seven and a half days.[[205]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Qun29Jan2020-206) In early and mid-January, the virus spread to other [Chinese provinces](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Provinces_of_China "Provinces of China"), helped by the [Chinese New Year migration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chunyun "Chunyun"). Wuhan was a transport hub and major rail interchange.[[206]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-WHO_report_28_February_2020-207) On 10 January, the virus' genome was shared publicly.[[207]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-208) A retrospective study published in March found that 6,174 people had reported symptoms by 20 January.[[208]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Epidemiology17Feb2020-209) A 24 January report indicated human transmission was likely occurring, and recommended [personal protective equipment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personal_protective_equipment "Personal protective equipment") for health workers. It also advocated testing, given the outbreak's "pandemic potential".[[209]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Huang24Jan2020-210)[[210]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Horton_18_March-211) On 30 January, 7,818 infections had been confirmed, leading WHO to declare the outbreak a [Public Health Emergency of International Concern](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_Health_Emergency_of_International_Concern "Public Health Emergency of International Concern") (PHEIC),[[211]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-WHO_PHEICSR-212)[[212]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-WHO_PHEIC_decl2-213)[[213]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-214) upgrading it to a pandemic on 11 March.[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-start-3) On 31 January, the first published modelling study warned of inevitable "independent self-sustaining outbreaks in major cities globally" and called for "large-scale public health interventions".[[214]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-pmid32014114-215)

By 31 January, Italy indicated its first confirmed infections had occurred, in two tourists from China.[[215]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Corriere_20Jan-216) The WHO announced on 11 March its assessment that the situation could be characterised as a pandemic.[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-start-3) On 19 March, Italy overtook China as the country with the most reported deaths.[[216]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-sky11960412-217)

By 26 March, the United States had overtaken China and Italy as the country with the highest number of confirmed infections.[[217]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-NYT-20200326-218) Genomic analysis indicated that the majority of [New York](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_New_York_(state) "COVID-19 pandemic in New York (state)")'s confirmed infections came from Europe, rather than directly from Asia.[[218]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200408nytimes-219) Testing of prior samples revealed a person who was infected in France on 27 December 2019[[219]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-France-retest-220)[[220]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Deslandes_2020-221) and a person in the United States who died from the disease on 6 February.[[221]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-PBS-2wks-222)

[![Image 38](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Covid-19_San_Salvatore_09.jpg/250px-Covid-19_San_Salvatore_09.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Covid-19_San_Salvatore_09.jpg)

An exhausted [anaesthesiologist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anesthesiology "Anesthesiology") in [Pesaro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pesaro "Pesaro"), Italy, 19 March 2020

In October, WHO reported that one in ten people around the world may have been infected, or 780 million people, while only 35 million infections had been confirmed.[[222]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-bbc_oneinten-223)

On 9 November, Pfizer released trial results for a candidate vaccine, showing a 90 per cent effectiveness in preventing infection. That day, Novavax submitted an FDA Fast Track application for their vaccine.[[223]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-FEv4C-224)[[224]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-NPZ5P-225) On 14 December, [Public Health England](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_Health_England "Public Health England") reported that a variant had been discovered in the UK's southeast, predominantly in [Kent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kent "Kent"). The variant, later named [Alpha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Variant_of_Concern_202012/01 "Variant of Concern 202012/01"), showed changes to the [spike protein](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coronavirus_spike_protein "Coronavirus spike protein") that could make the virus more infectious. As of 13 December, 1,108 infections had been confirmed in the UK.[[225]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-226)[[226]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-227) On 4 February 2020, US Secretary of Health and Human Services [Alex Azar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alex_Azar "Alex Azar") waived liability for vaccine manufacturers in all cases except those involving "willful misconduct".[[227]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-mXTUz-228)[[228]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-229)

triples.sentence: On 11 January, WHO was notified by the Chinese National Health Commission that the outbreak was associated with exposures in the market, and that China had identified a new type of coronavirus, which it isolated on 7 January.[[21]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-WHO_report-21)
triples.statement: On January 11, the WHO was notified by China's National Health Commission that the outbreak was linked to a market, and that China had identified and isolated a new coronavirus on January 7.

triples.sentence: On 10 January, the virus' genome was shared publicly.[[207]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-208)
triples.statement: On January 10, the virus's genome was shared publicly.

triples.sentence: A retrospective study published in March found that 6,174 people had reported symptoms by 20 January.[[208]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Epidemiology17Feb2020-209)
triples.statement: A retrospective study published in March found that 6,174 people had reported symptoms by January 20.

triples.sentence: On 30 January, 7,818 infections had been confirmed, leading WHO to declare the outbreak a [Public Health Emergency of International Concern](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_Health_Emergency_of_International_Concern "Public Health Emergency of International Concern") (PHEIC),[[211]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-WHO_PHEICSR-212)[[212]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-WHO_PHEIC_decl2-213)[[213]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-214) upgrading it to a pandemic on 11 March.[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-start-3)
triples.statement: With 7,818 confirmed infections by January 30, the WHO declared the outbreak a Public Health Emergency of International Concern (PHEIC), later upgrading it to a pandemic on March 11.

triples.sentence: Testing of prior samples revealed a person who was infected in France on 27 December 2019[[219]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-France-retest-220)[[220]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Deslandes_2020-221) and a person in the United States who died from the disease on 6 February.[[221]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-PBS-2wks-222)
triples.statement: Testing of prior samples revealed a person was infected in France on December 27, 2019, and a person in the United States died from the disease on February 6.

section_body:
Timelines of the COVID-19 pandemic in 2021 by month: [January](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_January_2021 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in January 2021"), [February](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_February_2021 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in February 2021"), [March](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_March_2021 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in March 2021"), [April](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_April_2021 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in April 2021"), [May](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_May_2021 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in May 2021"), [June](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_June_2021 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in June 2021"), [July](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_July_2021 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in July 2021"), [August](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_August_2021 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in August 2021"), [September](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_September_2021 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in September 2021"), [October](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_October_2021 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in October 2021"), [November](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_November_2021 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in November 2021"), [December](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_December_2021 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in December 2021")

On 2 January, the [Alpha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SARS-CoV-2_Alpha_variant "SARS-CoV-2 Alpha variant") variant, first discovered in the UK, had been identified in 33 countries.[[229]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-230) On 6 January, the [Gamma variant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lineage_P.1 "Lineage P.1") was first identified in Japanese travellers returning from Brazil.[[230]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-231) On 29 January, it was reported that the Novavax vaccine was 49 per cent effective against the [Beta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SARS-CoV-2_Beta_variant "SARS-CoV-2 Beta variant") variant in a clinical trial in South Africa.[[231]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-232)[[232]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-233) The [CoronaVac vaccine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CoronaVac_vaccine "CoronaVac vaccine") was reported to be 50.4 per cent effective in a Brazil clinical trial.[[233]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-234)

[![Image 39](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Covid-19_SP_-_Santo_Andre%27s_hospital_at_peak_of_pandemic.jpg/250px-Covid-19_SP_-_Santo_Andre%27s_hospital_at_peak_of_pandemic.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Covid-19_SP_-_Santo_Andre%27s_hospital_at_peak_of_pandemic.jpg)

A temporary hospital for COVID-19 patients in [Santo André](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Santo_Andr%C3%A9,_S%C3%A3o_Paulo "Santo André, São Paulo"), Brazil, in March 2021

On 12 March, several countries stopped using the [Oxford–AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oxford%E2%80%93AstraZeneca_COVID-19_vaccine "Oxford–AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine") due to blood clotting problems, specifically [cerebral venous sinus thrombosis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cerebral_venous_sinus_thrombosis "Cerebral venous sinus thrombosis") (CVST).[[234]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-235) On 20 March, the WHO and European Medicines Agency found no link to [thrombosis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thrombosis "Thrombosis"), leading several countries to resume administering the vaccine.[[235]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-236) In March WHO reported that an animal host was the most likely origin, without ruling out other possibilities.[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-who-origins-20210330-2)[[37]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Maxmen2021whoReport-37) The [Delta variant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SARS-CoV-2_Delta_variant "SARS-CoV-2 Delta variant") was first identified in India. In mid-April, the variant was first detected in the UK and two months later it had become a full-fledged third wave in the country, forcing the government to delay reopening that was originally scheduled for June.[[236]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-237) On 10 November, Germany advised against the [Moderna vaccine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moderna_COVID-19_vaccine "Moderna COVID-19 vaccine") for people under 30, due to a possible association with [myocarditis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Myocarditis "Myocarditis").[[237]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-238) On 24 November, the [Omicron variant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SARS-CoV-2_Omicron_variant "SARS-CoV-2 Omicron variant") was detected in South Africa; a few days later the WHO declared it a VoC (variant of concern).[[238]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-239) The new variant is more infectious than the Delta variant.[[239]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-240)

triples.sentence: On 29 January, it was reported that the Novavax vaccine was 49 per cent effective against the [Beta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SARS-CoV-2_Beta_variant "SARS-CoV-2 Beta variant") variant in a clinical trial in South Africa.[[231]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-232)[[232]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-233)
triples.statement: On 29 January, it was reported that the Novavax vaccine was 49 per cent effective against the Beta variant in a clinical trial in South Africa.

triples.sentence: The [CoronaVac vaccine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CoronaVac_vaccine "CoronaVac vaccine") was reported to be 50.4 per cent effective in a Brazil clinical trial.[[233]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-234)
triples.statement: The CoronaVac vaccine was reported to be 50.4 per cent effective in a Brazil clinical trial.

triples.sentence: In mid-April, the variant was first detected in the UK and two months later it had become a full-fledged third wave in the country, forcing the government to delay reopening that was originally scheduled for June.[[236]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-237)
triples.statement: In mid-April, the Delta variant was first detected in the UK and two months later it caused a third wave, forcing the government to delay a reopening scheduled for June.

section_body:
[![Image 40](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Novel_Coronavirus_SARS-CoV-2_%28Omicron%29_%2852665469105%29.jpg/250px-Novel_Coronavirus_SARS-CoV-2_%28Omicron%29_%2852665469105%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Novel_Coronavirus_SARS-CoV-2_(Omicron)_(52665469105).jpg)

Scanning electron micrograph (colorised) of cell infected with the Omicron strain of SARS-CoV-2 virus particles _green_

Timelines of the COVID-19 pandemic in 2022 by month: [January](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_January_2022 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in January 2022"), [February](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_February_2022 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in February 2022"), [March](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_March_2022 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in March 2022"), [April](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_April_2022 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in April 2022"), [May](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_May_2022 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in May 2022"), [June](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_June_2022 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in June 2022"), [July](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_July_2022 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in July 2022"), [August](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_August_2022 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in August 2022"), [September](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_September_2022 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in September 2022"), [October](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_October_2022 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in October 2022"), [November](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_November_2022 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in November 2022"), [December](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_December_2022 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in December 2022")

On 1 January, Europe passed 100 million cases amidst a surge in the [Omicron variant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SARS-CoV-2_Omicron_variant "SARS-CoV-2 Omicron variant").[[240]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-241) Later that month, the WHO recommended the [rheumatoid arthritis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rheumatoid_arthritis "Rheumatoid arthritis") drug [Baricitinib](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baricitinib "Baricitinib") for severe or critical patients. It also recommended the monoclonal antibody [Sotrovimab](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sotrovimab "Sotrovimab") in patients with non-severe disease, but only those who are at highest risk of hospitalisation.[[241]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-242)

On 24 January, the [Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Institute_for_Health_Metrics_and_Evaluation "Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation") estimated that about 57% of the world's population had been infected by COVID-19.[[64]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-57percent1-64)[[65]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-57percent2-65) By 6 March, it was reported that the total worldwide death count had surpassed 6 million people.[[242]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-243) By 6 July, Omicron subvariants [BA.4](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BA.4 "BA.4") and [BA.5](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BA.5 "BA.5") had spread worldwide.[[243]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-244) WHO Director-General Tedros Ghebreyesus stated on 14 September 2022, that "[The world has] never been in a better position to end the pandemic", citing the lowest number of weekly reported deaths since March 2020. He continued, "We are not there yet. But the end is in sight—we can see the finish line".[[244]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-245)[[245]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-246)[[246]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-247)[[247]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-248)

On 21 October, the United States surpassed 99 million cases of COVID-19, the most cases of any country.[[248]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-249) By 30 October, the worldwide daily death toll was 424, the lowest since 385 deaths were reported on 12 March 2020.[[249]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-250) 17 November marked the three-year anniversary since health officials in China first detected COVID-19.[[250]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-251)

On 11 November, the WHO reported that deaths since the month of February had dropped 90 per cent. Director-General Tedros said this was "cause for optimism".[[251]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-252) On 3 December, the WHO indicated that, "at least 90% of the world's population has some level of immunity to Sars-CoV-2".[[252]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-253) In early December, China began lifting some of its most stringent lockdown measures. Subsequent data from China's health authorities revealed that 248 million people, nearly 18 per cent of its population, had been infected in the first 20 days of that month.[[253]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-254) On 29 December, the US joined Italy, Japan, Taiwan and India in requiring negative COVID-19 test results from all people travelling from China due to the new surge in cases. The EU refused similar measures, stating that the BF7 omicron variant had already spread throughout Europe without becoming dominant.[[254]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-255)[[255]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-256)

triples.sentence: It also recommended the monoclonal antibody [Sotrovimab](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sotrovimab "Sotrovimab") in patients with non-severe disease, but only those who are at highest risk of hospitalisation.[[241]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-242)
triples.statement: The WHO also recommended the monoclonal antibody Sotrovimab for non-severe COVID-19 patients who are at the highest risk of hospitalization.

triples.sentence: On 24 January, the [Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Institute_for_Health_Metrics_and_Evaluation "Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation") estimated that about 57% of the world's population had been infected by COVID-19.[[64]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-57percent1-64)[[65]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-57percent2-65)
triples.statement: On January 24, 2022, the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation estimated that approximately 57% of the global population had been infected with COVID-19.

triples.sentence: By 6 July, Omicron subvariants [BA.4](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BA.4 "BA.4") and [BA.5](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BA.5 "BA.5") had spread worldwide.[[243]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-244)
triples.statement: By July 6, 2022, the Omicron subvariants BA.4 and BA.5 had spread globally.

triples.sentence: He continued, "We are not there yet. But the end is in sight—we can see the finish line".[[244]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-245)[[245]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-246)[[246]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-247)[[247]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-248)
triples.statement: WHO Director-General Tedros Ghebreyesus added, "We are not there yet. But the end is in sight—we can see the finish line".

triples.sentence: Director-General Tedros said this was "cause for optimism".[[251]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-252)
triples.statement: WHO Director-General Tedros called the 90% drop in deaths a "cause for optimism".

triples.sentence: Subsequent data from China's health authorities revealed that 248 million people, nearly 18 per cent of its population, had been infected in the first 20 days of that month.[[253]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-254)
triples.statement: Data from Chinese health authorities showed that 248 million people, almost 18% of the population, were infected in the first 20 days of December 2022.

triples.sentence: The EU refused similar measures, stating that the BF7 omicron variant had already spread throughout Europe without becoming dominant.[[254]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-255)[[255]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-256)
triples.statement: The EU declined to implement similar travel measures, stating the BF7 Omicron variant was already present in Europe but not dominant.

section_body:
[Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in 2023](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_2023 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in 2023")

On 4 January 2023, the WHO said the information shared by China during the recent surge in infections lacked data, such as hospitalisation rates.[[256]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-257) On 10 January, the WHO's Europe office said the recent viral surge in China posed "no immediate threat."[[257]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-258) On 16 January, the WHO recommended that China monitor excess mortality to provide "a more comprehensive understanding of the impact of COVID-19".[[258]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-259)

On 30 January, the three-year anniversary of the original declaration, the WHO determined that COVID-19 still met the criteria for a public health emergency of international concern (PHEIC).[[259]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-260)

On 19 March, WHO Director-General Tedros indicated he was "confident" the COVID-19 pandemic would cease to be a public health emergency by the end of the year.[[260]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-261) On 5 May, the WHO downgraded COVID-19 from being a global health emergency, though it continued to refer to it as a pandemic.[[261]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-262) The WHO does not make official declarations of when pandemics end.[[4]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-reuters-4)[[262]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-guardian-263) The decision came after Tedros convened with the International Health Regulations Emergency Committee, wherein the Committee noted that due to the decrease in deaths and hospitalisations, and the prevalence of vaccinations and the level of general immunity, it was time to remove the emergency designation and "transition to long-term management".[[263]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-WHO_Statement_5_May_2023-264) Tedros agreed, and the WHO reduced the classification to an "established and ongoing health issue".[[263]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-WHO_Statement_5_May_2023-264) In a press conference, Tedros remarked that the diminishing threat from COVID-19 had "allowed most countries to return to life as we knew it before COVID-19".[[264]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-npr-265)

In September the WHO said it had observed "concerning" trends in COVID-19 case numbers and hospitalisations, although analysis was hampered because many countries were no longer recording COVID-19 case statistics.[[265]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-266)

In November 2023, in response to viral mutations and changing characteristics of infection, the WHO adjusted its treatment guidelines. Among other changes, remdesivir and molnupiravir were now recommended only for the most severe cases, and [deuremidevir](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deuremidevir "Deuremidevir") and ivermectin were recommended against.[[266]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-267)

triples.sentence: On 4 January 2023, the WHO said the information shared by China during the recent surge in infections lacked data, such as hospitalisation rates.[[256]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-257)
triples.statement: On January 4, 2023, the WHO stated that information from China regarding a recent infection surge was missing data, including hospitalization rates.

triples.sentence: On 19 March, WHO Director-General Tedros indicated he was "confident" the COVID-19 pandemic would cease to be a public health emergency by the end of the year.[[260]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-261)
triples.statement: On March 19, WHO Director-General Tedros expressed confidence that the COVID-19 pandemic would no longer be considered a public health emergency by the end of the year.

triples.sentence: The decision came after Tedros convened with the International Health Regulations Emergency Committee, wherein the Committee noted that due to the decrease in deaths and hospitalisations, and the prevalence of vaccinations and the level of general immunity, it was time to remove the emergency designation and "transition to long-term management".[[263]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-WHO_Statement_5_May_2023-264)
triples.statement: The decision to remove the emergency designation was made after the International Health Regulations Emergency Committee noted decreases in deaths and hospitalizations, along with high levels of vaccination and general immunity, signaling a time to transition to long-term management.

triples.sentence: Tedros agreed, and the WHO reduced the classification to an "established and ongoing health issue".[[263]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-WHO_Statement_5_May_2023-264)
triples.statement: Following the committee's recommendation, WHO Director-General Tedros agreed to reduce the classification of COVID-19 to an "established and ongoing health issue."

triples.sentence: Among other changes, remdesivir and molnupiravir were now recommended only for the most severe cases, and [deuremidevir](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deuremidevir "Deuremidevir") and ivermectin were recommended against.[[266]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-267)
triples.statement: The updated WHO guidelines recommended remdesivir and molnupiravir only for severe cases and recommended against the use of deuremidevir and ivermectin.

section_body:
Main articles: [COVID-19 lockdowns](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_lockdowns "COVID-19 lockdowns"), [COVID-19 pandemic by country and territory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_by_country_and_territory "COVID-19 pandemic by country and territory"), and [National responses to the COVID-19 pandemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_responses_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic "National responses to the COVID-19 pandemic")

National reactions ranged from strict lockdowns to public education campaigns.[[267]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-IVdfl-268) WHO recommended that curfews and lockdowns should be short-term measures to reorganise, regroup, rebalance resources, and protect the health care system.[[268]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-58tIM-269) As of 26 March 2020, 1.7 billion people worldwide were under some form of lockdown.[[269]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-theguardian500000-270) This increased to 3.9 billion people by the first week of April—more than half the [world's population](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_population "World population").[[270]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200403euronews-271)[[271]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200328businessinsider-272)

In several countries, [protests rose against restrictions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Protests_against_responses_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic "Protests against responses to the COVID-19 pandemic") such as lockdowns. A February 2021 study found that protests against restrictions were likely to directly increase the spread of the virus.[[272]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-273)

triples.sentence: National reactions ranged from strict lockdowns to public education campaigns.[[267]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-IVdfl-268)
triples.statement: National reactions to the pandemic varied, ranging from strict lockdowns to public education campaigns.

triples.sentence: WHO recommended that curfews and lockdowns should be short-term measures to reorganise, regroup, rebalance resources, and protect the health care system.[[268]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-58tIM-269)
