triples.statement: The WHO recommended that curfews and lockdowns be used as short-term measures to reorganize resources and protect the healthcare system.

section_body:
Main article: [COVID-19 pandemic in Asia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Asia "COVID-19 pandemic in Asia")

As of the end of 2021, Asia's peak had come at the same time and at the same level as the world as a whole, in May 2021.[[273]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-274) However, cumulatively they had experienced only half of the global average in cases.[[274]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-275)

[![Image 41](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/%E5%A1%94%E5%AD%90%E6%B9%96%E4%BD%93%E8%82%B2%E4%B8%AD%E5%BF%83%E6%94%B9%E9%80%A0%E7%9A%84%E6%96%B9%E8%88%B1%E5%8C%BB%E9%99%A2_07.jpg/250px-%E5%A1%94%E5%AD%90%E6%B9%96%E4%BD%93%E8%82%B2%E4%B8%AD%E5%BF%83%E6%94%B9%E9%80%A0%E7%9A%84%E6%96%B9%E8%88%B1%E5%8C%BB%E9%99%A2_07.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:%E5%A1%94%E5%AD%90%E6%B9%96%E4%BD%93%E8%82%B2%E4%B8%AD%E5%BF%83%E6%94%B9%E9%80%A0%E7%9A%84%E6%96%B9%E8%88%B1%E5%8C%BB%E9%99%A2_07.jpg)

A [temporary hospital](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fangcang_Hospital "Fangcang Hospital") constructed in Wuhan in February 2020

China opted for containment, instituting strict lockdowns to eliminate viral spread.[[275]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-:02-276)[[276]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-277) The vaccines distributed in China included the [BIBP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sinopharm_BIBP_COVID-19_vaccine "Sinopharm BIBP COVID-19 vaccine"), [WIBP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sinopharm_WIBP_COVID-19_vaccine "Sinopharm WIBP COVID-19 vaccine"), and [CoronaVac](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CoronaVac "CoronaVac").[[277]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-278) It was reported on 11 December 2021, that China had vaccinated 1.162 billion of its citizens, or 82.5% of the total population of the country against COVID-19.[[278]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-279) China's large-scale adoption of [zero-COVID](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zero-COVID "Zero-COVID") had largely contained the first waves of infections of the disease.[[275]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-:02-276)[[279]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-280)[[280]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-281) When the waves of infections due to the [Omicron variant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SARS-CoV-2_Omicron_variant "SARS-CoV-2 Omicron variant") followed, China was almost alone in pursuing the strategy of zero-Covid to combat the spread of the virus in 2022.[[281]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-282) Lockdown continued to be employed in November to combat a new wave of cases;[[282]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-283)[[283]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-284) however, [protests erupted in cities across China](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_COVID-19_protests_in_China "2022 COVID-19 protests in China") over the country's stringent measures,[[284]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-285)[[285]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-286) and in December that year, the country relaxed its zero-COVID policy.[[286]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-287) On 20 December 2022, the Chinese State Council narrowed its definition of what would be counted as a COVID-19 death to include solely respiratory failure, which led to scepticism by health experts of the government's total death count[[287]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-288)[[288]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-289) at a time when hospitals reported being overwhelmed with cases following the abrupt discontinuation of zero-COVID.[[289]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-290)

The first case in India was reported on 30 January 2020. India ordered a nationwide lockdown starting 24 March 2020,[[290]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-mrGsK-291) with a phased unlock beginning 1 June 2020. Six cities accounted for around half of reported cases—[Mumbai](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Maharashtra "COVID-19 pandemic in Maharashtra"), [Delhi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Delhi "COVID-19 pandemic in Delhi"), [Ahmedabad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Gujarat "COVID-19 pandemic in Gujarat"), [Chennai](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Tamil_Nadu "COVID-19 pandemic in Tamil Nadu"), [Pune](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Maharashtra "COVID-19 pandemic in Maharashtra") and [Kolkata](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_West_Bengal "COVID-19 pandemic in West Bengal").[[291]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-sHMHJ-292) Post-lockdown, the Government of India introduced a contact tracking app called [Aarogya Setu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aarogya_Setu "Aarogya Setu") to help authorities manage contact tracing and vaccine distribution.[[292]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-293) India's vaccination programme was considered to be the world's largest and most successful with over 90% of citizens getting the first dose and another 65% getting the second dose.[[293]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-294)[[294]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-295) A second wave hit India in April 2021, straining healthcare services.[[295]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-296) On 21 October 2021, it was reported that the country had surpassed 1 billion vaccinations.[[296]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-297)

[![Image 42](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Disinfection_of_Tehran_subway_wagons_against_coronavirus_2020-02-26_09.jpg/250px-Disinfection_of_Tehran_subway_wagons_against_coronavirus_2020-02-26_09.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Disinfection_of_Tehran_subway_wagons_against_coronavirus_2020-02-26_09.jpg)

Disinfection of [Tehran Metro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran_Metro "Tehran Metro") trains to prevent COVID-19 transmission. Similar measures have also been taken in other countries.[[297]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-2kQpo-298)

Iran reported its first confirmed cases on 19 February 2020, in [Qom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qom "Qom").[[298]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-wHBRB-299)[[299]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-4yrqM-300) Early measures included the cancellation/closure of concerts and other cultural events,[[300]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Xm5nq-301) Friday prayers,[[301]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Urdn6-302) and school and university campuses.[[302]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-2YX6a-303) Iran became a centre of the pandemic in February 2020.[[303]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-HHOnl-304)[[304]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-New_Yorker-305) More than ten countries had traced their outbreaks to Iran by 28 February, indicating a more severe outbreak than the 388 reported cases.[[304]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-New_Yorker-305)[[305]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-D2Xpc-306) The [Iranian Parliament](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Islamic_Consultative_Assembly "Islamic Consultative Assembly") closed, after 23 of its 290 members tested positive on 3 March 2020.[[306]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-fXv2K-307) At least twelve sitting or former Iranian politicians and government officials had died by 17 March 2020.[[307]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-oxtUC-308) By August 2021, the pandemic's fifth wave peaked, with more than 400 deaths in 1 day.[[308]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-309)

COVID-19 was confirmed in South Korea on 20 January 2020. Military bases were quarantined after tests showed three infected soldiers.[[309]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-b82186-310) South Korea introduced what was then considered the world's largest and best-organised screening programme, isolating infected people, and tracing and quarantining contacts.[[310]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-science20200317-311) Screening methods included mandatory self-reporting by new international arrivals through mobile application,[[311]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-nbcnews1167376-312) combined with [drive-through](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Drive-through "Drive-through") testing,[[312]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-CvyZS-313) and increasing testing capability to 20,000 people/day.[[313]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-fdhQW-314) Despite some early criticisms,[[314]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-imx38-315) South Korea's programme was considered a success in controlling the outbreak without quarantining entire cities.[[310]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-science20200317-311)[[315]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Wypis-316)[[316]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-joins23778577-317)

triples.sentence: The vaccines distributed in China included the [BIBP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sinopharm_BIBP_COVID-19_vaccine "Sinopharm BIBP COVID-19 vaccine"), [WIBP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sinopharm_WIBP_COVID-19_vaccine "Sinopharm WIBP COVID-19 vaccine"), and [CoronaVac](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CoronaVac "CoronaVac").[[277]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-278)
triples.statement: Vaccines distributed in China included BIBP, WIBP, and CoronaVac.

triples.sentence: It was reported on 11 December 2021, that China had vaccinated 1.162 billion of its citizens, or 82.5% of the total population of the country against COVID-19.[[278]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-279)
triples.statement: On December 11, 2021, it was reported that China had vaccinated 1.162 billion people, representing 82.5% of its population.

triples.sentence: Lockdown continued to be employed in November to combat a new wave of cases;[[282]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-283)[[283]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-284) however, [protests erupted in cities across China](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_COVID-19_protests_in_China "2022 COVID-19 protests in China") over the country's stringent measures,[[284]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-285)[[285]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-286) and in December that year, the country relaxed its zero-COVID policy.[[286]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-287)
triples.statement: Lockdowns continued in November to combat a new wave of cases, but after protests erupted over the stringent measures, China relaxed its zero-COVID policy in December.

triples.sentence: On 20 December 2022, the Chinese State Council narrowed its definition of what would be counted as a COVID-19 death to include solely respiratory failure, which led to scepticism by health experts of the government's total death count[[287]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-288)[[288]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-289) at a time when hospitals reported being overwhelmed with cases following the abrupt discontinuation of zero-COVID.[[289]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-290)
triples.statement: On December 20, 2022, as hospitals were overwhelmed following the end of zero-COVID, the Chinese State Council narrowed the definition of a COVID-19 death to only include respiratory failure, leading to skepticism about the official death count.

triples.sentence: India ordered a nationwide lockdown starting 24 March 2020,[[290]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-mrGsK-291) with a phased unlock beginning 1 June 2020.
triples.statement: India implemented a nationwide lockdown on March 24, 2020, and began a phased reopening on June 1, 2020.

triples.sentence: Iran reported its first confirmed cases on 19 February 2020, in [Qom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qom "Qom").[[298]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-wHBRB-299)[[299]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-4yrqM-300)
triples.statement: Iran's first confirmed COVID-19 cases were reported in Qom on February 19, 2020.

triples.sentence: Early measures included the cancellation/closure of concerts and other cultural events,[[300]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Xm5nq-301) Friday prayers,[[301]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Urdn6-302) and school and university campuses.[[302]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-2YX6a-303)
triples.statement: Early measures in Iran included closing concerts, cultural events, Friday prayers, schools, and universities.

triples.sentence: Screening methods included mandatory self-reporting by new international arrivals through mobile application,[[311]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-nbcnews1167376-312) combined with [drive-through](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Drive-through "Drive-through") testing,[[312]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-CvyZS-313) and increasing testing capability to 20,000 people/day.[[313]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-fdhQW-314)
triples.statement: South Korea's screening methods included mandatory self-reporting for international arrivals via a mobile app, drive-through testing, and a testing capacity of 20,000 people per day.

triples.sentence: Despite some early criticisms,[[314]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-imx38-315) South Korea's programme was considered a success in controlling the outbreak without quarantining entire cities.[[310]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-science20200317-311)[[315]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Wypis-316)[[316]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-joins23778577-317)
triples.statement: Despite initial criticism, South Korea's program was deemed successful in controlling the outbreak without implementing city-wide quarantines.

section_body:
Main article: [COVID-19 pandemic in Europe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Europe "COVID-19 pandemic in Europe")

[![Image 43](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Persons_died_due_to_coronavirus_COVID-19_per_capita_in_Europe.svg/500px-Persons_died_due_to_coronavirus_COVID-19_per_capita_in_Europe.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Persons_died_due_to_coronavirus_COVID-19_per_capita_in_Europe.svg)

Deaths per 100,000 residents

The COVID-19 pandemic arrived in Europe with its first confirmed case in [Bordeaux](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bordeaux "Bordeaux"), [France](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_France "COVID-19 pandemic in France"), on 24 January 2020, and subsequently spread widely across the continent. By 17 March 2020, every country in Europe had confirmed a case,[[317]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-318) and all had reported at least one death, with the exception of [Vatican City](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Vatican_City "COVID-19 pandemic in Vatican City"). Italy was the first European nation to experience a major outbreak in early 2020, becoming the first country worldwide to introduce a national [lockdown](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_lockdowns_in_Italy "COVID-19 lockdowns in Italy").[[318]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-319) By 13 March 2020, the WHO declared Europe the epicentre of the pandemic[[319]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-320)[[320]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-321) and it remained so until the WHO announced it had been overtaken by [South America](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_South_America "COVID-19 pandemic in South America") on 22 May.[[321]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-322) By 18 March 2020, more than 250 million people were in [lockdown](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stay-at-home_order "Stay-at-home order") in Europe.[[322]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-323) Despite [deployment of COVID-19 vaccines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deployment_of_COVID-19_vaccines "Deployment of COVID-19 vaccines"), Europe became the pandemic's epicentre once again in late 2021.[[323]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-324)[[324]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-325)

The [Italian outbreak](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Italy "COVID-19 pandemic in Italy") began on 31 January 2020, when two Chinese tourists tested positive for SARS-CoV-2 in Rome.[[215]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Corriere_20Jan-216) Cases began to rise sharply, which prompted the government to suspend flights to and from China and declare a state of emergency.[[325]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-thelocal-flight-326) On 22 February 2020, the Council of Ministers announced a new decree-law to contain the outbreak, which quarantined more than 50,000 people in northern Italy.[[326]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AutoDW-201-327) On 4 March, the Italian government ordered schools and universities closed as Italy reached a hundred deaths. Sport was suspended completely for at least one month.[[327]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Kv4Ld-328) On 11 March, Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte closed down nearly all commercial activity except supermarkets and pharmacies.[[328]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-To26Y-329)[[329]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-ClzT6-330) On 19 April, the first wave ebbed, as 7-day deaths declined to 433.[[330]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-thehill493586-331) On 13 October, the Italian government again issued restrictive rules to contain the second wave.[[331]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-KhaW7-332) On 10 November, Italy surpassed 1 million confirmed infections.[[332]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-8XEwk-333) On 23 November, it was reported that the second wave of the virus had led some hospitals to stop accepting patients.[[333]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-334)

[![Image 44: Elderly woman rolls up sleeve as two nurses administer a vaccine.](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/2020_12_27_mas_vacunados_en_la_residencia_mixta_1_%28cropped%29.jpg/250px-2020_12_27_mas_vacunados_en_la_residencia_mixta_1_%28cropped%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:2020_12_27_mas_vacunados_en_la_residencia_mixta_1_(cropped).jpg)

Vaccinations at a [retirement home](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Retirement_home "Retirement home") in [Gijón](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gij%C3%B3n "Gijón"), Spain on 12 December 2020

The virus was first confirmed to have spread to Spain on 31 January 2020, when a German tourist tested positive for SARS-CoV-2 on [La Gomera](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/La_Gomera "La Gomera") in the Canary Islands.[[334]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-SanidadConfirmaEnLaGomera-335) Post-hoc genetic analysis has shown that at least 15 strains of the virus had been imported, and [community transmission](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Community_transmission "Community transmission") began by mid-February.[[335]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-genetic_analysis-336) On 29 March, it was announced that, beginning the following day, all non-essential workers were ordered to remain at home for the next 14 days.[[336]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-337) The number of cases increased again in July in a number of cities including [Barcelona](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barcelona "Barcelona"), [Zaragoza](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zaragoza "Zaragoza") and [Madrid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madrid "Madrid"), which led to reimposition of some restrictions but no national lockdown.[[337]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-bbc25july-338)[[338]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-elpais6aug-339)[[339]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-telegraph_aug16-340)[[340]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-341) By September 2021, Spain was one of the countries with the highest percentage of its population vaccinated (76% fully vaccinated and 79% with the first dose).[[341]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-auto2-342) Italy is ranked second at 75%.[[341]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-auto2-342)

Sweden differed from most other European countries in that it mostly remained open.[[342]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-NYT20200515-343) Per the [Swedish constitution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swedish_constitution "Swedish constitution"), the [Public Health Agency of Sweden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_Health_Agency_of_Sweden "Public Health Agency of Sweden") has autonomy that prevents political interference and the agency favoured remaining open. The Swedish strategy focused on longer-term measures, based on the assumption that after lockdown the virus would resume spreading, with the same result.[[343]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-7ys2k-344)[[344]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-I06mN-345) By the end of June, Sweden no longer had [excess mortality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Excess_mortality "Excess mortality").[[345]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-HEUrz-346)

[Devolution in the United Kingdom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Devolution_in_the_United_Kingdom "Devolution in the United Kingdom") meant that each of its four [countries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Countries_of_the_United_Kingdom "Countries of the United Kingdom") developed its own response. England's restrictions were shorter-lived than the others.[[346]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-8VnMf-347) The [UK government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government_of_the_United_Kingdom "Government of the United Kingdom") started enforcing social distancing and quarantine measures on 18 March 2020.[[347]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-PkWGD-348)[[348]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Pkx25-349) On 16 March, Prime Minister [Boris Johnson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boris_Johnson "Boris Johnson") advised against non-essential travel and social contact, praising [work from home](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Remote_work "Remote work") and avoiding venues such as pubs, restaurants, and theatres.[[349]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-5Q93q-350)[[350]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-hYdUy-351) On 20 March, the government ordered all leisure establishments to close,[[351]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-dmBNt-352) and promised to prevent unemployment.[[352]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-mV2p3-353) On 23 March, Johnson banned gatherings and restricted non-essential travel and outdoor activity. Unlike previous measures, these restrictions were enforceable by police through fines and dispersal of gatherings. Most non-essential businesses were ordered to close.[[353]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-bbc-pm-2403-354) On 24 April 2020, it was reported that a promising vaccine trial had begun in England; the government pledged more than £50 million towards research.[[354]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-vKeXC-355) On 16 April 2020, it was reported that the UK would have first access to the Oxford vaccine, due to a prior contract; should the trial be successful, some 30 million doses would be available.[[355]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Lbt4o-356) On 2 December 2020, the UK became the first developed country to approve the Pfizer vaccine; 800,000 doses were immediately available for use.[[356]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-357) In August 2022 it was reported that viral infection cases had declined in the UK.[[357]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-358)

triples.sentence: By 13 March 2020, the WHO declared Europe the epicentre of the pandemic[[319]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-320)[[320]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-321) and it remained so until the WHO announced it had been overtaken by [South America](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_South_America "COVID-19 pandemic in South America") on 22 May.[[321]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-322)
triples.statement: The WHO declared Europe the pandemic's epicentre by March 13, 2020, a status it held until South America overtook it on May 22.

triples.sentence: Cases began to rise sharply, which prompted the government to suspend flights to and from China and declare a state of emergency.[[325]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-thelocal-flight-326)
triples.statement: A sharp rise in cases led the Italian government to suspend flights with China and declare a state of emergency.

triples.sentence: On 22 February 2020, the Council of Ministers announced a new decree-law to contain the outbreak, which quarantined more than 50,000 people in northern Italy.[[326]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AutoDW-201-327)
triples.statement: On February 22, 2020, the Italian Council of Ministers issued a decree-law that quarantined over 50,000 people in northern Italy to contain the outbreak.

triples.sentence: On 29 March, it was announced that, beginning the following day, all non-essential workers were ordered to remain at home for the next 14 days.[[336]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-337)
triples.statement: An announcement on March 29 ordered all non-essential workers in Spain to stay home for 14 days, starting the next day.

triples.sentence: The number of cases increased again in July in a number of cities including [Barcelona](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barcelona "Barcelona"), [Zaragoza](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zaragoza "Zaragoza") and [Madrid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madrid "Madrid"), which led to reimposition of some restrictions but no national lockdown.[[337]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-bbc25july-338)[[338]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-elpais6aug-339)[[339]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-telegraph_aug16-340)[[340]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-341)
triples.statement: In July, case numbers rose again in cities like Barcelona, Zaragoza, and Madrid, resulting in some new restrictions but not a national lockdown.

triples.sentence: On 16 March, Prime Minister [Boris Johnson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boris_Johnson "Boris Johnson") advised against non-essential travel and social contact, praising [work from home](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Remote_work "Remote work") and avoiding venues such as pubs, restaurants, and theatres.[[349]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-5Q93q-350)[[350]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-hYdUy-351)
triples.statement: On March 16, Prime Minister Boris Johnson recommended against non-essential travel and social contact, encouraging working from home and avoiding places like pubs, restaurants, and theatres.

triples.sentence: On 16 April 2020, it was reported that the UK would have first access to the Oxford vaccine, due to a prior contract; should the trial be successful, some 30 million doses would be available.[[355]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Lbt4o-356)
triples.statement: A report on April 16, 2020, indicated that a prior contract would give the UK first access to the Oxford vaccine, with about 30 million doses available if the trial succeeded.

section_body:
Main article: [COVID-19 pandemic in North America](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_North_America "COVID-19 pandemic in North America")

The virus arrived in the [United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_the_United_States "COVID-19 pandemic in the United States") on 13 January 2020.[[358]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-359) Cases were reported in all North American countries after [Saint Kitts and Nevis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Saint_Kitts_and_Nevis "COVID-19 pandemic in Saint Kitts and Nevis") confirmed a case on 25 March, and in all North American territories after [Bonaire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Bonaire "COVID-19 pandemic in Bonaire") confirmed a case on 16 April.[[359]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-FirstBonaire_local-360)

[![Image 45](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/USNS_Comfort_New_York_City_2020.jpg/250px-USNS_Comfort_New_York_City_2020.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:USNS_Comfort_New_York_City_2020.jpg)

The hospital ship [USNS _Comfort_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USNS_Comfort "USNS Comfort") arrives in [Manhattan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manhattan "Manhattan") on 30 March 2020

Per _Our World in Data_, 103,436,829[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Template:COVID-19_data-5) confirmed cases have been reported in the United States with 1,228,289[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Template:COVID-19_data-5) deaths, the most of any country, and [the nineteenth-highest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_death_rates_by_country "COVID-19 pandemic death rates by country") per capita worldwide.[[360]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-JH_Mortality-361) COVID-19 is the [deadliest pandemic in US history](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_disasters_in_the_United_States_by_death_toll "List of disasters in the United States by death toll");[[361]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-362) it was the third-leading cause of death in the US in 2020, behind heart disease and cancer.[[362]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-363) From 2019 to 2020, US life expectancy dropped by 3 years for Hispanic Americans, 2.9 years for African Americans, and 1.2 years for white Americans.[[363]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Bosman-364) These effects have persisted as US deaths due to COVID-19 in 2021 exceeded those in 2020.[[364]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-365) In the United States, COVID-19 vaccines became available under emergency use in December 2020, beginning the [national vaccination programme](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_vaccination_in_the_United_States "COVID-19 vaccination in the United States"). The first COVID-19 vaccine was officially approved by the [Food and Drug Administration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Food_and_Drug_Administration "Food and Drug Administration") on 23 August 2021.[[365]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-366) By 18 November 2022, while cases in the U.S. had declined, COVID variants BQ.1/BQ.1.1 had become dominant in the country.[[366]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-367)[[367]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-368)

In March 2020, as cases of community transmission were confirmed across [Canada](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Canada "COVID-19 pandemic in Canada"), all of its provinces and territories declared states of emergency. Provinces and territories, to varying degrees, implemented school and daycare closures, prohibitions on gatherings, closures of non-essential businesses and restrictions on entry. Canada severely restricted its border access, barring travellers from all countries with some exceptions.[[368]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-369) Cases surged across Canada, notably in the provinces of [British Columbia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_British_Columbia "COVID-19 pandemic in British Columbia"), [Alberta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Alberta "COVID-19 pandemic in Alberta"), [Quebec](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Quebec "COVID-19 pandemic in Quebec") and [Ontario](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Ontario "COVID-19 pandemic in Ontario"), with the formation of the [Atlantic Bubble](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atlantic_Bubble "Atlantic Bubble"), a [travel-restricted](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Travel_restrictions_related_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic "Travel restrictions related to the COVID-19 pandemic") area of the country (formed of the four [Atlantic provinces](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atlantic_Canada "Atlantic Canada")).[[369]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-370) Vaccine passports were adopted in all provinces and two of the territories.[[370]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-371)[[371]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-372) Per a report on 11 November 2022, Canadian health authorities saw a surge in influenza, while COVID-19 was expected to rise during winter.[[372]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-373)

triples.sentence: COVID-19 is the [deadliest pandemic in US history](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_disasters_in_the_United_States_by_death_toll "List of disasters in the United States by death toll");[[361]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-362) it was the third-leading cause of death in the US in 2020, behind heart disease and cancer.[[362]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-363)
triples.statement: COVID-19 is the deadliest pandemic in US history and was the third-leading cause of death in the US in 2020, after heart disease and cancer.

triples.sentence: From 2019 to 2020, US life expectancy dropped by 3 years for Hispanic Americans, 2.9 years for African Americans, and 1.2 years for white Americans.[[363]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Bosman-364)
triples.statement: Between 2019 and 2020, US life expectancy decreased by 3 years for Hispanic Americans, 2.9 years for African Americans, and 1.2 years for white Americans.

triples.sentence: Canada severely restricted its border access, barring travellers from all countries with some exceptions.[[368]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-369)
triples.statement: Canada significantly restricted its border access, banning travelers from all countries with few exceptions.

triples.sentence: Vaccine passports were adopted in all provinces and two of the territories.[[370]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-371)[[371]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-372)
triples.statement: All Canadian provinces and two territories adopted vaccine passports.

section_body:
Main article: [COVID-19 pandemic in South America](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_South_America "COVID-19 pandemic in South America")

[![Image 46](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Fosas_comunes_en_Cochabamba.jpg/250px-Fosas_comunes_en_Cochabamba.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Fosas_comunes_en_Cochabamba.jpg)

Mass graves being prepared for COVID-19 victims in [Cochabamba](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cochabamba "Cochabamba"), Bolivia

The COVID-19 pandemic was confirmed to have reached South America on 26 February 2020, when Brazil confirmed a case in [São Paulo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo "São Paulo").[[373]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-374) By 3 April, all countries and territories in South America had recorded at least one case.[[374]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Stuff/Fairfax-375) On 13 May 2020, it was reported that Latin America and the [Caribbean](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Caribbean "Caribbean") had reported over 400,000 cases of COVID-19 infection with 23,091 deaths. On 22 May 2020, citing the rapid increase of [infections in Brazil](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Brazil "COVID-19 pandemic in Brazil"), the WHO declared South America the epicentre of the pandemic.[[375]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-376)[[376]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-377) As of 16 July 2021, South America had recorded 34,359,631 confirmed cases and 1,047,229 deaths from COVID-19. Due to a shortage of testing and medical facilities, it is believed that the outbreak is far larger than the official numbers show.[[377]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-378)

The virus was confirmed to have spread to Brazil on 25 February 2020,[[378]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-379) when a man from [São Paulo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo "São Paulo") who had travelled to Italy tested positive for the virus.[[379]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-380) The disease had spread to every [federative unit of Brazil](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federative_units_of_Brazil "Federative units of Brazil") by 21 March. On 19 June 2020, the country reported its one millionth case and nearly 49,000 reported deaths.[[380]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-381)[[381]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-382) One estimate of [under-reporting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Under-reporting#Disease "Under-reporting") was 22.62% of total reported COVID-19 mortality in 2020.[[382]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-383)[[383]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-384)[[384]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-385) As of 05 December 2025, Brazil, with 37,903,843[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Template:COVID-19_data-5) confirmed cases and 703,536[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Template:COVID-19_data-5) deaths, has the third-highest number of confirmed cases and second-highest death toll from COVID-19 in the world, behind only [those of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_the_United_States "COVID-19 pandemic in the United States") and [India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_India "COVID-19 pandemic in India").[[385]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-386)

triples.sentence: The COVID-19 pandemic was confirmed to have reached South America on 26 February 2020, when Brazil confirmed a case in [São Paulo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo "São Paulo").[[373]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-374)
triples.statement: The COVID-19 pandemic was confirmed to have reached South America on February 26, 2020, when Brazil confirmed a case in São Paulo.

triples.sentence: By 3 April, all countries and territories in South America had recorded at least one case.[[374]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Stuff/Fairfax-375)
triples.statement: By April 3, 2020, all countries and territories in South America had recorded at least one case of COVID-19.

triples.sentence: As of 05 December 2025, Brazil, with 37,903,843[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Template:COVID-19_data-5) confirmed cases and 703,536[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Template:COVID-19_data-5) deaths, has the third-highest number of confirmed cases and second-highest death toll from COVID-19 in the world, behind only [those of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_the_United_States "COVID-19 pandemic in the United States") and [India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_India "COVID-19 pandemic in India").[[385]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-386)
triples.statement: As of December 5, 2025, Brazil had the third-highest number of confirmed COVID-19 cases (37,903,843) and the second-highest death toll (703,536) in the world, behind only the United States and India.

section_body:
Main article: [COVID-19 pandemic in Africa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Africa "COVID-19 pandemic in Africa")

[![Image 47](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Air_Forces_Africa_delivers_medical_supplies_to_Ghana_%2849829156488%29.jpg/250px-Air_Forces_Africa_delivers_medical_supplies_to_Ghana_%2849829156488%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Air_Forces_Africa_delivers_medical_supplies_to_Ghana_(49829156488).jpg)

[US Air Force](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Air_Force "United States Air Force") personnel unload a [C-17](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_C-17_Globemaster_III "Boeing C-17 Globemaster III") aircraft carrying medical supplies in [Niamey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Niamey "Niamey"), Niger, in April 2020.

The COVID-19 pandemic was confirmed to have spread to Africa on 14 February 2020, with the first confirmed case announced in [Egypt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Egypt "COVID-19 pandemic in Egypt").[[386]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-bbc_51509248-387)[[387]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-388) The first confirmed case in [sub-Saharan Africa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sub-Saharan_Africa "Sub-Saharan Africa") was announced in [Nigeria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Nigeria "COVID-19 pandemic in Nigeria") at the end of February 2020.[[388]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-bbc_51671834-389) Within three months, the virus had spread throughout the continent; [Lesotho](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Lesotho "COVID-19 pandemic in Lesotho"), the last African sovereign state to have remained free of the virus, reported its first case on 13 May 2020.[[389]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-reuters_idUSKBN22P1R4-390)[[390]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-latimes.com-391) By 26 May, it appeared that most African countries were experiencing community transmission, although testing capacity was limited.[[391]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-theguardian_20200526_africa-392) Most of the identified imported cases arrived from Europe and the United States rather than from China where the virus originated.[[392]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Africa_Braces-393) Many preventive measures [were implemented](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_responses_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_Africa "National responses to the COVID-19 pandemic in Africa") by different countries in Africa including travel restrictions, flight cancellations, and event cancellations.[[393]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-394) Despite fears, Africa reported lower death rates than other, more economically developed regions.[[394]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-NYT_Africa_deaths-395)

In early June 2021, Africa faced a third wave of COVID infections with cases rising in 14 countries.[[395]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-theguardian_20210607_third-396) By 4 July the continent recorded more than 251,000 new COVID cases, a 20% increase from the prior week and a 12% increase from the January peak. More than sixteen African countries, including [Malawi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Malawi "COVID-19 pandemic in Malawi") and [Senegal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Senegal "COVID-19 pandemic in Senegal"), recorded an uptick in new cases.[[396]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Mendez-397) The WHO labelled it Africa's 'Worst Pandemic Week Ever'.[[397]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-398) In October 2022, WHO reported that most countries on the African continent will miss the goal of 70 per cent vaccination by the end of 2022.[[398]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-399)

triples.sentence: The COVID-19 pandemic was confirmed to have spread to Africa on 14 February 2020, with the first confirmed case announced in [Egypt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Egypt "COVID-19 pandemic in Egypt").[[386]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-bbc_51509248-387)[[387]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-388)
triples.statement: The COVID-19 pandemic was confirmed to have spread to Africa on February 14, 2020, with the first case announced in Egypt.

triples.sentence: Most of the identified imported cases arrived from Europe and the United States rather than from China where the virus originated.[[392]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Africa_Braces-393)
triples.statement: Most identified imported COVID-19 cases in Africa came from Europe and the United States, not from China where the virus originated.

triples.sentence: The WHO labelled it Africa's 'Worst Pandemic Week Ever'.[[397]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-398)
triples.statement: The WHO labeled the period as Africa's 'Worst Pandemic Week Ever'.

triples.sentence: In October 2022, WHO reported that most countries on the African continent will miss the goal of 70 per cent vaccination by the end of 2022.[[398]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-399)
triples.statement: In October 2022, the WHO reported that most countries in Africa would miss the 70 percent vaccination goal by the end of 2022.

section_body:
Main article: [COVID-19 pandemic in Oceania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Oceania "COVID-19 pandemic in Oceania")

[![Image 48](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Empty_shelves_at_Coles_during_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_Brisbane%2C_Australia.jpg/250px-Empty_shelves_at_Coles_during_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_Brisbane%2C_Australia.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Empty_shelves_at_Coles_during_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_Brisbane,_Australia.jpg)

Empty shelves at a [Coles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coles_Supermarkets "Coles Supermarkets") grocery store in [Brisbane](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brisbane "Brisbane"), Australia, in April 2020

The COVID-19 pandemic was confirmed to have reached Oceania on 25 January 2020, with the first confirmed case reported in [Melbourne](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Melbourne "Melbourne"), [Australia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Australia "COVID-19 pandemic in Australia").[[399]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AustraliaCase1-400)[[400]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Brisbane2021-401) It has since spread elsewhere in the region.[[401]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-WHO_Dashboard-402)[[400]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Brisbane2021-401)[Australia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Australia "COVID-19 pandemic in Australia") and [New Zealand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_New_Zealand "COVID-19 pandemic in New Zealand") were praised for their handling of the pandemic in comparison to other Western nations, with New Zealand and each state in Australia wiping out all community transmission of the virus several times even after re-introduction into the community.[[402]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-reuters-oz-10days-403)[[403]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-bloomberg-oz-tassie-price-404)[[404]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-405)

As a result of the high transmissibility of the Delta variant, however, by August 2021, the Australian states of [New South Wales](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_South_Wales "New South Wales") and [Victoria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Victoria_(Australia) "Victoria (Australia)") had conceded defeat in their eradication efforts.[[405]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-406) In early October 2021, New Zealand also abandoned its elimination strategy.[[406]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-The_Guardian_NZ_abandons_elimination-407) In November and December, following vaccination efforts, the remaining states of Australia, excluding Western Australia, voluntarily gave up [COVID-Zero](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zero-COVID "Zero-COVID") to open up state and international borders.[[407]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-408)[[408]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-409)[[409]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-410) The open borders allowed the Omicron variant of COVID-19 to enter quickly, and cases subsequently exceeded 120,000 a day.[[410]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-411) By early March 2022, with cases exceeding 1,000 a day, Western Australia conceded defeat in its eradication strategy and opened its borders.[[411]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-412) Despite record cases, Australian jurisdictions slowly removed restrictions such as close contact isolation, mask wearing, and density limits by April 2022.[[412]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-413)

On 9 September 2022, restrictions were significantly relaxed. The aircraft mask mandate was scrapped nationwide, and daily reporting transitioned to weekly reporting.[[413]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-414)[[414]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-415)[[415]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-416) On 14 September, COVID-19 disaster payment for isolating persons was extended for mandatory isolation.[[416]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-417) By 22 September, all states had ended mask mandates on public transport, including in Victoria, where the mandate had lasted for approximately 800 days.[[417]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-418) On 30 September 2022, all Australian leaders declared the emergency response finished and announced the end of isolation requirements. These changes were due in part to high levels of 'hybrid immunity' and low case numbers.[[418]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-419)

triples.sentence: [Australia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Australia "COVID-19 pandemic in Australia") and [New Zealand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_New_Zealand "COVID-19 pandemic in New Zealand") were praised for their handling of the pandemic in comparison to other Western nations, with New Zealand and each state in Australia wiping out all community transmission of the virus several times even after re-introduction into the community.[[402]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-reuters-oz-10days-403)[[403]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-bloomberg-oz-tassie-price-404)[[404]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-405)
triples.statement: Australia and New Zealand were praised for their pandemic response compared to other Western nations, having eliminated community transmission of the virus multiple times.

triples.sentence: In November and December, following vaccination efforts, the remaining states of Australia, excluding Western Australia, voluntarily gave up [COVID-Zero](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zero-COVID "Zero-COVID") to open up state and international borders.[[407]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-408)[[408]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-409)[[409]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-410)
triples.statement: Following vaccination efforts in November and December, all Australian states except Western Australia abandoned the COVID-Zero strategy to reopen state and international borders.

triples.sentence: The open borders allowed the Omicron variant of COVID-19 to enter quickly, and cases subsequently exceeded 120,000 a day.[[410]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-411)
triples.statement: The open borders facilitated the rapid entry of the Omicron variant, leading to daily cases exceeding 120,000.

section_body:
Main article: [COVID-19 pandemic in Antarctica](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Antarctica "COVID-19 pandemic in Antarctica")

Due to its remoteness and sparse population, [Antarctica](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antarctica "Antarctica") was the last continent to have confirmed cases of COVID-19.[[419]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-420)[[420]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-421)[[421]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-422) The first cases were reported in December 2020, almost a year after the first cases of COVID-19 were detected in China. At least 36 people were infected in the first outbreak in 2020,[[422]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-423) with several other outbreaks taking place in 2021 and 2022.[[423]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-424)

triples.sentence: Due to its remoteness and sparse population, [Antarctica](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antarctica "Antarctica") was the last continent to have confirmed cases of COVID-19.[[419]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-420)[[420]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-421)[[421]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-422)
triples.statement: Due to its remoteness and sparse population, Antarctica was the last continent to have confirmed cases of COVID-19.

triples.sentence: At least 36 people were infected in the first outbreak in 2020,[[422]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-423) with several other outbreaks taking place in 2021 and 2022.[[423]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-424)
triples.statement: At least 36 people were infected in the first outbreak in 2020, with several other outbreaks occurring in 2021 and 2022.

section_body:
Main article: [United Nations response to the COVID-19 pandemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Nations_response_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic "United Nations response to the COVID-19 pandemic")

The [United Nations Conference on Trade and Development](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Nations_Conference_on_Trade_and_Development "United Nations Conference on Trade and Development") (UNSC) was criticised for its slow response, especially regarding the UN's [global ceasefire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_ceasefire "Global ceasefire"), which aimed to open up humanitarian access to conflict zones.[[424]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-:22-425)[[425]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Krm4a-426) The United Nations Security Council was criticised due to the inadequate manner in which it dealt with the COVID-19 pandemic, namely the poor ability to create international collaboration during this crisis.[[426]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-427)[[427]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-428)

On 23 March 2020, United Nations Secretary-General [António Manuel de Oliveira Guterres](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ant%C3%B3nio_Guterres "António Guterres") appealed for a global [ceasefire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ceasefire "Ceasefire");[[428]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-tFb4N-429)[[429]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-lzoeV-430) 172 UN member states and observers signed a non-binding supporting statement in June,[[430]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AGhvz-431) and the [UN Security Council](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UN_Security_Council "UN Security Council") passed a [resolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council_Resolution_2532 "United Nations Security Council Resolution 2532") supporting it in July.[[431]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-9rN79-432)[[432]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-nJTuX-433)

On 29 September 2020, Guterres urged the [International Monetary Fund](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund "International Monetary Fund") to help certain countries via debt relief and also call for countries to increase contributions to develop vaccines.[[433]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-434)

triples.sentence: The United Nations Security Council was criticised due to the inadequate manner in which it dealt with the COVID-19 pandemic, namely the poor ability to create international collaboration during this crisis.[[426]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-427)[[427]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-428)
triples.statement: The United Nations Security Council was criticized for its inadequate handling of the COVID-19 pandemic, specifically its poor ability to foster international collaboration.

triples.sentence: On 23 March 2020, United Nations Secretary-General [António Manuel de Oliveira Guterres](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ant%C3%B3nio_Guterres "António Guterres") appealed for a global [ceasefire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ceasefire "Ceasefire");[[428]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-tFb4N-429)[[429]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-lzoeV-430) 172 UN member states and observers signed a non-binding supporting statement in June,[[430]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AGhvz-431) and the [UN Security Council](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UN_Security_Council "UN Security Council") passed a [resolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council_Resolution_2532 "United Nations Security Council Resolution 2532") supporting it in July.[[431]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-9rN79-432)[[432]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-nJTuX-433)
triples.statement: On March 23, 2020, UN Secretary-General António Guterres appealed for a global ceasefire; subsequently, 172 UN member states and observers signed a non-binding supporting statement in June, and the UN Security Council passed a supportive resolution in July.

triples.sentence: On 29 September 2020, Guterres urged the [International Monetary Fund](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund "International Monetary Fund") to help certain countries via debt relief and also call for countries to increase contributions to develop vaccines.[[433]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-434)
triples.statement: On September 29, 2020, UN Secretary-General Guterres urged the International Monetary Fund to provide debt relief to certain countries and called for increased contributions towards vaccine development.

section_body:
Main article: [World Health Organization's response to the COVID-19 pandemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Health_Organization%27s_response_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic "World Health Organization's response to the COVID-19 pandemic")

[![Image 49](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/13981214000744637189356214810969_%D9%86%D8%B4%D8%B3%D8%AA_%D9%85%D8%AF%DB%8C%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%86_%D8%B4%D9%87%D8%B1%DB%8C_%D8%A8%D8%A7_%D9%86%D9%85%D8%A7%DB%8C%D9%86%D8%AF%DA%AF%D8%A7%D9%86_%D8%B3%D8%A7%D8%B2%D9%85%D8%A7%D9%86_%D8%A8%D9%87%D8%AF%D8%A7%D8%B4%D8%AA_%D8%AC%D9%87%D8%A7%D9%86%DB%8C.jpg/250px-13981214000744637189356214810969_%D9%86%D8%B4%D8%B3%D8%AA_%D9%85%D8%AF%DB%8C%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%86_%D8%B4%D9%87%D8%B1%DB%8C_%D8%A8%D8%A7_%D9%86%D9%85%D8%A7%DB%8C%D9%86%D8%AF%DA%AF%D8%A7%D9%86_%D8%B3%D8%A7%D8%B2%D9%85%D8%A7%D9%86_%D8%A8%D9%87%D8%AF%D8%A7%D8%B4%D8%AA_%D8%AC%D9%87%D8%A7%D9%86%DB%8C.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:13981214000744637189356214810969_%D9%86%D8%B4%D8%B3%D8%AA_%D9%85%D8%AF%DB%8C%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%86_%D8%B4%D9%87%D8%B1%DB%8C_%D8%A8%D8%A7_%D9%86%D9%85%D8%A7%DB%8C%D9%86%D8%AF%DA%AF%D8%A7%D9%86_%D8%B3%D8%A7%D8%B2%D9%85%D8%A7%D9%86_%D8%A8%D9%87%D8%AF%D8%A7%D8%B4%D8%AA_%D8%AC%D9%87%D8%A7%D9%86%DB%8C.jpg)

[World Health Organization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Health_Organization "World Health Organization") representatives holding joint meeting with [Tehran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran "Tehran") city administrators in March 2020

The WHO spearheaded initiatives such as the [COVID-19 Solidarity Response Fund](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_Solidarity_Response_Fund "COVID-19 Solidarity Response Fund") to raise money for the pandemic response, the [UN COVID-19 Supply Chain Task Force](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UN_COVID-19_Supply_Chain_Task_Force "UN COVID-19 Supply Chain Task Force"), and the [solidarity trial](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solidarity_trial "Solidarity trial") for investigating potential treatment options for the disease. The [COVAX](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVAX "COVAX") programme, co-led by the WHO, [GAVI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GAVI "GAVI"), and the [Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coalition_for_Epidemic_Preparedness_Innovations "Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations") (CEPI), aimed to accelerate the development, manufacture, and distribution of COVID-19 vaccines, and to guarantee fair and equitable access across the world.[[434]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-435)[[435]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-436)

triples.sentence: The [COVAX](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVAX "COVAX") programme, co-led by the WHO, [GAVI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GAVI "GAVI"), and the [Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coalition_for_Epidemic_Preparedness_Innovations "Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations") (CEPI), aimed to accelerate the development, manufacture, and distribution of COVID-19 vaccines, and to guarantee fair and equitable access across the world.[[434]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-435)[[435]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-436)
triples.statement: The COVAX programme, co-led by the WHO, GAVI, and the Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations (CEPI), aimed to accelerate the development, manufacture, and distribution of COVID-19 vaccines and to guarantee fair and equitable access globally.

section_body:
Further information: [Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic") and [International aid related to the COVID-19 pandemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_aid_related_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic "International aid related to the COVID-19 pandemic")

[![Image 50: Workers unloading boxes of medical supplies at Villamor Air Base.](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/China_COVID19_test_kit_PH_donation_8.jpg/250px-China_COVID19_test_kit_PH_donation_8.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:China_COVID19_test_kit_PH_donation_8.jpg)

Donated medical supplies received in the Philippines

The pandemic shook the world's economy, with especially severe economic damage in the United States, Europe and Latin America.[[436]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-437)[[437]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Effect_of_COVID-19_on_food_security-438) A consensus report by American intelligence agencies in April 2021 concluded, "Efforts to contain and manage the virus have reinforced nationalist trends globally, as some states turned inward to protect their citizens and sometimes cast blame on marginalised groups". COVID-19 inflamed partisanship and polarisation around the world as bitter arguments exploded over how to respond. International trade was disrupted amid the formation of no-entry enclaves.[[438]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-439)

triples.sentence: International trade was disrupted amid the formation of no-entry enclaves.[[438]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-439)
triples.statement: The formation of no-entry enclaves disrupted international trade.

section_body:
Main article: [Travel restrictions related to the COVID-19 pandemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Travel_restrictions_related_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic "Travel restrictions related to the COVID-19 pandemic")

The pandemic led many countries and regions to impose quarantines, entry bans, or other restrictions, either for citizens, recent travellers to affected areas,[[439]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200326nytimes-440) or for all travellers.[[440]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-441)[[441]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-442) Travel collapsed worldwide, damaging the travel sector. The effectiveness of travel restrictions was questioned as the virus spread across the world.[[442]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200224nationalgeographic-443) One study found that travel restrictions only modestly affected the initial spread, unless combined with other [infection prevention and control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infection_prevention_and_control "Infection prevention and control") measures.[[443]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-DJYtB-444)[[444]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-445) Researchers concluded that "travel restrictions are most useful in the early and late phase of an epidemic" and "restrictions of travel from Wuhan unfortunately came too late".[[445]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-283GD-446) The European Union rejected the idea of suspending the [Schengen free travel zone](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schengen_Agreement "Schengen Agreement").[[446]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-dw52497811-447)[[447]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200313euractiv-448)

triples.sentence: Researchers concluded that "travel restrictions are most useful in the early and late phase of an epidemic" and "restrictions of travel from Wuhan unfortunately came too late".[[445]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-283GD-446)
triples.statement: Researchers concluded that travel restrictions are most effective early and late in an epidemic, and that the restrictions on travel from Wuhan were implemented too late.

triples.sentence: The European Union rejected the idea of suspending the [Schengen free travel zone](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schengen_Agreement "Schengen Agreement").[[446]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-dw52497811-447)[[447]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200313euractiv-448)
triples.statement: The European Union decided against suspending the Schengen free travel zone.

section_body:
Main article: [Evacuations related to the COVID-19 pandemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evacuations_related_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic "Evacuations related to the COVID-19 pandemic")

[![Image 51](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Ukraine_evacuates_Ukrainian_and_foreign_citizens_from_Wuhan_16.jpg/250px-Ukraine_evacuates_Ukrainian_and_foreign_citizens_from_Wuhan_16.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Ukraine_evacuates_Ukrainian_and_foreign_citizens_from_Wuhan_16.jpg)

Ukraine evacuates Ukrainian citizens from [Wuhan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wuhan "Wuhan"), China.

Several countries repatriated their citizens and diplomatic staff from Wuhan and surrounding areas, primarily through [charter flights](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Air_charter "Air charter"). Canada, the United States, Japan, India, Sri Lanka, Australia, France, Argentina, Germany and Thailand were among the first to do so.[[448]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AutoDW-169-449) Brazil and New Zealand evacuated their own nationals and others.[[449]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AutoDW-171-450)[[450]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-6l9jG-451) On 14 March, South Africa repatriated 112 South Africans who tested negative, while four who showed symptoms were left behind.[[451]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-auto3-452) Pakistan declined to evacuate its citizens.[[452]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200131dialoguepakistan-453)

On 15 February, the US announced it would evacuate Americans aboard the _[Diamond Princess](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diamond\_Princess\_outbreak "Diamond Princess outbreak")_ cruise ship,[[453]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AutoDW-174-454) and on 21 February, Canada evacuated 129 Canadians from the ship.[[454]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AutoDW-175-455) In early March, the Indian government began repatriating its citizens from Iran.[[455]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-czjOG-456)[[456]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-indiatimes74647353-457) On 20 March, the United States began to withdraw some troops from Iraq.[[457]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-USWithdraw-458)

triples.sentence: On 14 March, South Africa repatriated 112 South Africans who tested negative, while four who showed symptoms were left behind.[[451]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-auto3-452)
triples.statement: On March 14, South Africa repatriated 112 of its citizens who tested negative, while four who showed symptoms were not evacuated.

triples.sentence: Pakistan declined to evacuate its citizens.[[452]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200131dialoguepakistan-453)
triples.statement: Pakistan declined to evacuate its citizens.

section_body:
Main article: [Economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic "Economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic")

See also: [Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on aviation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_on_aviation "Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on aviation"), [on science and technology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_on_science_and_technology "Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on science and technology"), [on financial markets](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Financial_market_impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic "Financial market impact of the COVID-19 pandemic"), [2020 stock market crash](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_stock_market_crash "2020 stock market crash"), and [COVID-19 recession](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_recession "COVID-19 recession")

[![Image 52](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Stock-indices-2020crash%2Brecovery.svg/330px-Stock-indices-2020crash%2Brecovery.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Stock-indices-2020crash%2Brecovery.svg)

A [stock index](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stock_index "Stock index") chart shows the [2020 stock market crash](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_stock_market_crash "2020 stock market crash").

The pandemic and responses to it damaged the global economy. On 27 February 2020, worries about the outbreak crushed US stock indexes, which posted their sharpest falls since 2008.[[458]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-U7teI-459)

Tourism collapsed due to travel restrictions, closing of public places including travel attractions, and advice of governments against travel. Airlines cancelled flights, while British regional airline [Flybe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flybe_(1979%E2%80%932020) "Flybe (1979–2020)") collapsed.[[459]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-z2VrM-460) The cruise line industry was hard hit,[[460]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-smh20200227-461) and train stations and ferry ports closed.[[461]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-wnn7L-462) International mail stopped or was delayed.[[462]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-wsj1158868721-463)

The retail sector faced reductions in store hours or closures.[[463]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-464) Retailers in Europe and Latin America faced traffic declines of 40 per cent. North America and Middle East retailers saw a 50–60 per cent drop.[[464]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200402aislelabs-465) Shopping centres faced a 33–43 per cent drop in foot traffic in March compared to February. Mall operators around the world coped by increasing sanitation, installing thermal scanners to check the temperature of shoppers, and cancelling events.[[465]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-J6Y6Z-466)

Hundreds of millions of jobs were lost,[[466]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-aljazeera2004271718-467)[[467]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200506csmonitor-468) including more than 40 million jobs in the US.[[468]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200528WaPo-469) According to a report by [Yelp](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yelp "Yelp"), about 60% of US businesses that closed will stay shut permanently.[[469]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-vLHxV-470) The [International Labour Organization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Labour_Organization "International Labour Organization") (ILO) reported that the income generated in the first nine months of 2020 from work across the world dropped by 10.7%, or $3.5 trillion.[[470]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-rd8bm-471)

triples.sentence: International mail stopped or was delayed.[[462]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-wsj1158868721-463)
triples.statement: International mail was stopped or delayed.

triples.sentence: The retail sector faced reductions in store hours or closures.[[463]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-464)
triples.statement: The retail sector experienced reductions in store hours or closures.

triples.sentence: North America and Middle East retailers saw a 50–60 per cent drop.[[464]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200402aislelabs-465)
triples.statement: Retailers in North America and the Middle East saw a 50–60 percent drop in traffic.

triples.sentence: Mall operators around the world coped by increasing sanitation, installing thermal scanners to check the temperature of shoppers, and cancelling events.[[465]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-J6Y6Z-466)
triples.statement: Mall operators worldwide responded by increasing sanitation, installing thermal scanners to check shoppers' temperatures, and cancelling events.

section_body:
Main article: [Shortages related to the COVID-19 pandemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shortages_related_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic "Shortages related to the COVID-19 pandemic")

[![Image 53](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Ntuc_super_store%2C_Singapore_%2849505410793%29.jpg/250px-Ntuc_super_store%2C_Singapore_%2849505410793%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Ntuc_super_store,_Singapore_(49505410793).jpg)

COVID-19 fears led to panic buying of essentials across the world, including toilet paper, instant noodles, bread, rice, vegetables, disinfectant, and rubbing alcohol (picture taken in February 2020).

Pandemic fears led to [panic buying](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panic_buying "Panic buying"), emptying groceries of essentials such as food, toilet paper, and bottled water. Panic buying stemmed from perceived threat, perceived scarcity, fear of the unknown, coping behaviour and social psychological factors (e.g. [social influence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_influence "Social influence") and trust).[[471]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-cSvA4-472)

Supply [shortages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shortage "Shortage") were due to disruption to factory and logistic operations; shortages were worsened by [supply chain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supply_chain "Supply chain") disruptions from factory and port shutdowns, and labour shortages.[[472]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-XvcU9-473)

Shortages continued as managers underestimated the speed of economic recovery after the initial economic crash. The technology industry, in particular, warned of delays from underestimates of [semiconductor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semiconductor "Semiconductor") demand for vehicles and other products.[[473]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AutoDW-263-474)

According to WHO Secretary-General Tedros Ghebreyesus, demand for [personal protective equipment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personal_protective_equipment "Personal protective equipment") (PPE) rose one hundredfold, pushing prices up twentyfold.[[474]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AutoDW-275-475)[[475]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AutoDW-276-476) PPE stocks were exhausted everywhere.[[476]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Mycfo-477)[[477]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-478)[[478]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-479)

In September 2021, the [World Bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Bank "World Bank") reported that food prices remained generally stable and the supply outlook remained positive.
