However, the poorest countries witnessed a sharp increase in food prices, reaching the highest level since the pandemic began.[[479]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-480)[[480]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-auto4-481) The Agricultural Commodity Price Index stabilised in the third quarter but remained 17% higher than in January 2021.[[481]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-482)[[480]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-auto4-481)

By contrast, petroleum products were in surplus at the beginning of the pandemic, as demand for gasoline and other products collapsed due to reduced commuting and other trips.[[482]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-BBC,_US_oil_prices,_21_April_2020-483) The [2021 global energy crisis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_global_energy_crisis "2021 global energy crisis") was driven by a global surge in demand as the world economy recovered. Energy demand was particularly strong in Asia.[[483]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-484)[[484]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-485)

triples.sentence: The technology industry, in particular, warned of delays from underestimates of [semiconductor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semiconductor "Semiconductor") demand for vehicles and other products.[[473]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AutoDW-263-474)
triples.statement: The technology industry warned of delays resulting from underestimations of semiconductor demand for vehicles and other products.

triples.sentence: According to WHO Secretary-General Tedros Ghebreyesus, demand for [personal protective equipment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personal_protective_equipment "Personal protective equipment") (PPE) rose one hundredfold, pushing prices up twentyfold.[[474]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AutoDW-275-475)[[475]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AutoDW-276-476)
triples.statement: According to WHO Secretary-General Tedros Ghebreyesus, demand for personal protective equipment (PPE) increased 100-fold, which caused prices to rise 20-fold.

triples.sentence: PPE stocks were exhausted everywhere.[[476]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Mycfo-477)[[477]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-478)[[478]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-479)
triples.statement: Supplies of personal protective equipment (PPE) were depleted globally.

section_body:
Main article: [Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the arts and cultural heritage](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_on_the_arts_and_cultural_heritage "Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the arts and cultural heritage")

The performing arts and [cultural heritage sectors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cultural_heritage_sector "Cultural heritage sector") were profoundly affected by the pandemic. Both organisations' and individuals' operations have been impacted globally. By March 2020, across the world and to varying degrees, museums, libraries, performance venues, and other cultural institutions had been indefinitely closed with their exhibitions, events and performances cancelled or postponed.[[485]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-v5Qlx-486) A 2021 [UNESCO](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UNESCO "UNESCO") report estimated ten million job losses worldwide in the culture and creative industries.[[486]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Ottone-487)[[487]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-488) Some services continued through digital platforms,[[488]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-ZljIY-489)[[489]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Burke2020-490)[[490]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-SxIEK-491) such as live streaming concerts[[491]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-SZ5Mc-492) or web-based arts festivals.[[492]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-mYlLn-493)

triples.sentence: A 2021 [UNESCO](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UNESCO "UNESCO") report estimated ten million job losses worldwide in the culture and creative industries.[[486]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Ottone-487)[[487]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-488)
triples.statement: A 2021 UNESCO report estimated ten million job losses worldwide in the culture and creative industries.

triples.sentence: Some services continued through digital platforms,[[488]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-ZljIY-489)[[489]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Burke2020-490)[[490]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-SxIEK-491) such as live streaming concerts[[491]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-SZ5Mc-492) or web-based arts festivals.[[492]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-mYlLn-493)
triples.statement: Some services, such as live streaming concerts or web-based arts festivals, continued through digital platforms.

section_body:
Main article: [Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on politics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_on_politics "Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on politics")

See also: [Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on international relations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_on_international_relations "Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on international relations")

The pandemic affected political systems, causing suspensions of legislative activities,[[493]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200313nationalpost-494) isolations or deaths of politicians,[[494]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200318foreignpolicy-495) and rescheduled elections.[[495]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200427nytimes-496) Although they developed broad support among epidemiologists, NPIs (non-pharmaceutical interventions) were controversial in many countries. Intellectual opposition came primarily from other fields, along with heterodox epidemiologists.[[496]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-74OHE-497)

triples.sentence: Intellectual opposition came primarily from other fields, along with heterodox epidemiologists.[[496]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-74OHE-497)
triples.statement: Intellectual opposition to non-pharmaceutical interventions came mainly from other fields and from heterodox epidemiologists.

section_body:
The pandemic (and the [response of Brazilian politicians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Brazil#Responses "COVID-19 pandemic in Brazil") to it) led to widespread panic, confusion, and pessimism in Brazil.[[497]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-BenderdaSilvaBaum2022-498) When questioned regarding record deaths in the country in April 2020, Brazilian president [Jair Bolsonaro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jair_Bolsonaro "Jair Bolsonaro") said "So what? I'm sorry. What do you want me to do about it?"[[498]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Conde_2020-499) Bolsonaro disregarded WHO-recommended mitigation techniques and instead [downplayed the risks of the virus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Brazil#Comments_by_Bolsonaro "COVID-19 pandemic in Brazil"), promoted increased economic activity, spread [misinformation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Brazil#Presidential_responses "COVID-19 pandemic in Brazil") about the efficacy of masks, vaccines and public health measures, and distributed unproven treatments including [hydroxychloroquine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chloroquine_and_hydroxychloroquine_during_the_COVID-19_pandemic "Chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine during the COVID-19 pandemic") and [ivermectin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ivermectin_during_the_COVID-19_pandemic "Ivermectin during the COVID-19 pandemic").[[497]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-BenderdaSilvaBaum2022-498) A series of [federal health ministers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Ministers_of_Health_of_Brazil "List of Ministers of Health of Brazil") resigned or were dismissed after they refused to implement Bolsonaro's policies.[[499]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Londono2020-500)

Disagreements between federal and state governments led to a chaotic and delayed response to the rapid spread of the virus,[[500]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Dantas2020-501) exacerbated by preexisting social and economic disparities in the country.[[497]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-BenderdaSilvaBaum2022-498)[[501]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-CarnutMendesGuerra2020-502) Employment, investment and valuation of the [Brazilian real](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brazilian_real "Brazilian real") plummeted to record lows.[[497]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-BenderdaSilvaBaum2022-498)[[502]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-ReutersBrazil2020-503) Brazil was also heavily affected by the Delta and Omicron variants.[[503]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AlcantaraNogueiraShuabTosta2022-504) At the height of the outbreak in the spring of 2021, 3,000+ Brazilians were dying per day.[[504]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-BBCBrazilMarch2021-505)[[505]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-NPRBrazilApril2021-506) Bolsonaro's loss to [Lula da Silva](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lula_da_Silva "Lula da Silva") in the [2022 presidential election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_Brazilian_general_election "2022 Brazilian general election") is widely credited to the former's [mishandling of the pandemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Presidency_of_Jair_Bolsonaro#Response_to_COVID-19_pandemic "Presidency of Jair Bolsonaro").[[506]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-ChomskyPolychroniou2023-507)[[507]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-EconomistBolsonaroLoss2022-508)[[508]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Milhorance2022October-509)

triples.sentence: Disagreements between federal and state governments led to a chaotic and delayed response to the rapid spread of the virus,[[500]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Dantas2020-501) exacerbated by preexisting social and economic disparities in the country.[[497]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-BenderdaSilvaBaum2022-498)[[501]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-CarnutMendesGuerra2020-502)
triples.statement: Disagreements between federal and state governments led to a chaotic and delayed response to the virus, which was worsened by existing social and economic disparities in Brazil.

triples.sentence: Employment, investment and valuation of the [Brazilian real](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brazilian_real "Brazilian real") plummeted to record lows.[[497]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-BenderdaSilvaBaum2022-498)[[502]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-ReutersBrazil2020-503)
triples.statement: Employment, investment, and the valuation of the Brazilian real fell to record lows.

triples.sentence: Bolsonaro's loss to [Lula da Silva](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lula_da_Silva "Lula da Silva") in the [2022 presidential election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_Brazilian_general_election "2022 Brazilian general election") is widely credited to the former's [mishandling of the pandemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Presidency_of_Jair_Bolsonaro#Response_to_COVID-19_pandemic "Presidency of Jair Bolsonaro").[[506]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-ChomskyPolychroniou2023-507)[[507]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-EconomistBolsonaroLoss2022-508)[[508]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Milhorance2022October-509)
triples.statement: Jair Bolsonaro's loss to Lula da Silva in the 2022 presidential election is widely attributed to his mishandling of the pandemic.

section_body:
Further information: [China–United States relations §COVID-19](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China%E2%80%93United_States_relations#COVID-19 "China–United States relations")

Multiple provincial-level administrators of the [Chinese Communist Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_Communist_Party "Chinese Communist Party") (CCP) were dismissed over their handling of quarantine measures. Some commentators claimed this move was intended to protect CCP General Secretary [Xi Jinping](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xi_Jinping "Xi Jinping").[[509]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-vLpPa-510) The [US intelligence community](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/US_intelligence_community "US intelligence community") claimed that China intentionally under-reported its COVID-19 caseload.[[510]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200402nytimes-511) The Chinese government maintained that it acted swiftly and transparently.[[511]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-hMc3w-512)[[512]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-513) Journalists and activists in China who reported on the pandemic were detained by authorities,[[513]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-514)[[514]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-515) including [Zhang Zhan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zhang_Zhan "Zhang Zhan"), who was arrested and tortured.[[515]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-516)[[516]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-517)

triples.sentence: The Chinese government maintained that it acted swiftly and transparently.[[511]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-hMc3w-512)[[512]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-513)
triples.statement: The Chinese government maintained that its actions were swift and transparent.

triples.sentence: Journalists and activists in China who reported on the pandemic were detained by authorities,[[513]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-514)[[514]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-515) including [Zhang Zhan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zhang_Zhan "Zhang Zhan"), who was arrested and tortured.[[515]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-516)[[516]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-517)
triples.statement: Journalists and activists in China who reported on the pandemic were detained by authorities, including Zhang Zhan, who was arrested and tortured.

section_body:
[![Image 55](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Open_Ohio_Rally_IMG_0910_%2849799974031%29.jpg/250px-Open_Ohio_Rally_IMG_0910_%2849799974031%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Open_Ohio_Rally_IMG_0910_(49799974031).jpg)

Anti-lockdown [protesters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Protests_over_responses_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic "Protests over responses to the COVID-19 pandemic") rallied at [Ohio Statehouse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ohio_Statehouse "Ohio Statehouse") 20 April 2020.[[524]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Columbus_Dispatch-525)

Beginning in mid-April 2020, protestors objected to government-imposed business closures and restrictions on personal movement and assembly.[[525]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-5YqAF-526) Simultaneously, [essential workers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Essential_workers "Essential workers") protested unsafe conditions and low wages by participating in a brief [general strike](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_strike "General strike").[[526]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-c114M-527) Some political analysts claimed that the pandemic contributed to US president [Donald Trump](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump")'s [2020](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_United_States_presidential_election "2020 United States presidential election") defeat.[[527]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-TrumpChances-528)[[528]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AtlanticChances-529)

The [COVID-19 pandemic in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_the_United_States "COVID-19 pandemic in the United States") prompted calls for the United States to adopt social policies common in other wealthy countries, including [universal health care](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universal_health_care "Universal health care"), [universal child care](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universal_child_care "Universal child care"), [paid sick leave](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paid_sick_leave "Paid sick leave"), and higher levels of funding for public health.[[529]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-NYT_Calls-530)[[530]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Hill5-531)[[531]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Ddn2P-532) The [Kaiser Family Foundation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kaiser_Family_Foundation "Kaiser Family Foundation") estimated that preventable hospitalisations of unvaccinated Americans in the second half of 2021 cost US$13.8 billion.[[532]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Amin-533)

There were also protest in regards to vaccine mandates in the United States.[[533]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-534) In January 2022, the US Supreme Court struck down an OSHA rule that mandated vaccination or a testing regimen for all companies with greater than 100 employees.[[534]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-535)[[535]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-536)

triples.sentence: Simultaneously, [essential workers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Essential_workers "Essential workers") protested unsafe conditions and low wages by participating in a brief [general strike](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_strike "General strike").[[526]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-c114M-527)
triples.statement: At the same time, essential workers protested unsafe conditions and low wages by taking part in a brief general strike.

triples.sentence: Some political analysts claimed that the pandemic contributed to US president [Donald Trump](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump")'s [2020](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_United_States_presidential_election "2020 United States presidential election") defeat.[[527]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-TrumpChances-528)[[528]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AtlanticChances-529)
triples.statement: Some political analysts claimed the pandemic contributed to US President Donald Trump's 2020 election defeat.

triples.sentence: The [COVID-19 pandemic in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_the_United_States "COVID-19 pandemic in the United States") prompted calls for the United States to adopt social policies common in other wealthy countries, including [universal health care](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universal_health_care "Universal health care"), [universal child care](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universal_child_care "Universal child care"), [paid sick leave](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paid_sick_leave "Paid sick leave"), and higher levels of funding for public health.[[529]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-NYT_Calls-530)[[530]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Hill5-531)[[531]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Ddn2P-532)
triples.statement: The COVID-19 pandemic in the United States led to calls for the adoption of social policies common in other wealthy nations, such as universal health care, universal child care, paid sick leave, and increased public health funding.

section_body:
The number of journalists imprisoned or detained increased worldwide; some detentions were related to the pandemic.[[536]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-537)[[537]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-538) The planned [NATO](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NATO "NATO") "[Defender 2020](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_NATO_exercises#2020 "List of NATO exercises")" military exercise in Germany, [Poland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poland "Poland") and the [Baltic states](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baltic_states "Baltic states"), the largest NATO war exercise since the end of the [Cold War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cold_War "Cold War"), was held on a reduced scale.[[538]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200320spectator-539)[[539]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200319reuters-540)

The Iranian government was heavily affected by the virus, which infected some two dozen parliament members and political figures.[[305]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-D2Xpc-306)[[540]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-541) Iranian president [Hassan Rouhani](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hassan_Rouhani "Hassan Rouhani") wrote a public letter to world leaders asking for help on 14 March 2020, due to a lack of access to international markets.[[541]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-u2rRX-542) Saudi Arabia, which had launched a [military intervention in Yemen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saudi_Arabian-led_intervention_in_Yemen "Saudi Arabian-led intervention in Yemen") in March 2015, declared a ceasefire.[[542]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200409foreignpolicy-543)

Diplomatic relations between [Japan and South Korea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japan%E2%80%93South_Korea_relations "Japan–South Korea relations") worsened.[[543]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-544) South Korea criticised Japan's "ambiguous and passive quarantine efforts" after Japan announced travellers from South Korea must quarantine for two weeks.[[544]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-HnqN4-545) South Korean society was initially polarised on president [Moon Jae-in](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moon_Jae-in "Moon Jae-in")'s response to the crisis; many Koreans signed petitions calling for Moon's [impeachment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impeachment "Impeachment") or praising his response.[[314]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-imx38-315)

Some countries passed emergency legislation. Some commentators expressed concern that it could allow governments to strengthen their grip on power.[[545]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200331theguardian-546)[[546]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200330nytimes-547) In Hungary, the parliament voted to allow Prime Minister [Viktor Orbán](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Viktor_Orb%C3%A1n "Viktor Orbán") to rule by decree indefinitely, suspend parliament and elections, and punish those deemed to have spread false information.[[547]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200330cnn-548) In countries such as [Egypt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Egypt "Egypt"),[[548]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-dw53009293-549)[Turkey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turkey "Turkey"),[[549]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200401foreignpolicy-550) and [Thailand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thailand "Thailand"),[[550]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-551) opposition activists and government critics were [arrested](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Misinformation_related_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic#Efforts_to_combat_misinformation "Misinformation related to the COVID-19 pandemic") for allegedly spreading [fake news](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fake_news "Fake news").[[551]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200410straitstimes-552) In [India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_India "COVID-19 pandemic in India"), journalists criticising the government's response were arrested or issued warnings by police and authorities.[[552]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-553)

triples.sentence: The planned [NATO](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NATO "NATO") "[Defender 2020](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_NATO_exercises#2020 "List of NATO exercises")" military exercise in Germany, [Poland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poland "Poland") and the [Baltic states](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baltic_states "Baltic states"), the largest NATO war exercise since the end of the [Cold War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cold_War "Cold War"), was held on a reduced scale.[[538]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200320spectator-539)[[539]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200319reuters-540)
triples.statement: The 'Defender 2020' NATO military exercise in Germany, Poland, and the Baltic states, the largest since the Cold War, was held on a reduced scale.

triples.sentence: South Korean society was initially polarised on president [Moon Jae-in](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moon_Jae-in "Moon Jae-in")'s response to the crisis; many Koreans signed petitions calling for Moon's [impeachment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impeachment "Impeachment") or praising his response.[[314]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-imx38-315)
triples.statement: South Korean society was initially polarized regarding President Moon Jae-in's response to the crisis, with petitions circulating both for his impeachment and in praise of his actions.

triples.sentence: In countries such as [Egypt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Egypt "Egypt"),[[548]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-dw53009293-549)[Turkey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turkey "Turkey"),[[549]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200401foreignpolicy-550) and [Thailand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thailand "Thailand"),[[550]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-551) opposition activists and government critics were [arrested](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Misinformation_related_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic#Efforts_to_combat_misinformation "Misinformation related to the COVID-19 pandemic") for allegedly spreading [fake news](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fake_news "Fake news").[[551]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200410straitstimes-552)
triples.statement: In countries like Egypt, Turkey, and Thailand, opposition activists and government critics were arrested for allegedly spreading fake news.

section_body:
Main articles: [Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on other health issues](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_on_other_health_issues "Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on other health issues") and [Mental health during the COVID-19 pandemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mental_health_during_the_COVID-19_pandemic "Mental health during the COVID-19 pandemic")

The pandemic impacted global health for many conditions. Hospital visits fell.[[562]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-563) Visits for heart attack symptoms declined by 38% in the US and 40% in Spain.[[563]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-564) The head of cardiology at the [University of Arizona](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Arizona "University of Arizona") said, "My worry is some of these people are dying at home because they're too scared to go to the hospital".[[564]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Stat_News,_with_serious_heart_symptoms_away,_April_23-565) People with strokes and [appendicitis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Appendicitis "Appendicitis") were less likely to seek treatment.[[565]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-566)[[566]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-567)[[564]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Stat_News,_with_serious_heart_symptoms_away,_April_23-565)[Medical supply shortages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shortages_related_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic "Shortages related to the COVID-19 pandemic") impacted many people.[[567]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Atlantic_Shortages-568) The pandemic impacted [mental health](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mental_health "Mental health"),[[568]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-569)[[569]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Stix_2021-570) increasing [anxiety](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anxiety "Anxiety"), depression, and [post-traumatic stress disorder](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Post-traumatic_stress_disorder "Post-traumatic stress disorder"), affecting healthcare workers, patients and quarantined individuals.[[570]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-571)[[571]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Santomauro_2021-572)

In late 2022, during the first northern hemisphere autumn and winter seasons following the widespread relaxation of global public health measures, North America and Europe experienced a surge in respiratory viruses and coinfections in both adults and children.[[572]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-573) This formed the beginning of the 2022–2023 paediatric care crisis and what some experts termed a "[tripledemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tripledemic "Tripledemic")" of seasonal influenza, [respiratory syncytial virus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Respiratory_syncytial_virus "Respiratory syncytial virus") (RSV), and SARS-CoV-2 throughout North America.[[573]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-574)[[574]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-575) In the United Kingdom, paediatric infections also began to spike beyond pre-pandemic levels, albeit with different illnesses, such as [Group A streptococcal infection](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Group_A_streptococcal_infection "Group A streptococcal infection") and resultant [scarlet fever](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scarlet_fever "Scarlet fever").[[575]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-576)[[576]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-United_Kingdom-577) As of mid-December 2022, 19 children in the UK had died due to [Strep A](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Streptococcus_pyogenes "Streptococcus pyogenes") and the wave of infections had begun to spread into North America and Mainland Europe.[[577]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Strep_A_death-578)[[578]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Strep_Expansion-579)

The B/Yamagata lineage of [influenza B](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Influenza_B "Influenza B") might have become extinct in 2020/2021 due to COVID-19 pandemic measures.[[579]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Alhoufie2021-580)[[580]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Koutsakos2021-581) There have been no naturally occurring cases confirmed since March 2020.[[581]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-WHOflu2023-582)[[582]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-UMN2023-583) In 2023, the WHO concluded that protection against the Yamagata lineage was no longer necessary in the seasonal [flu vaccine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flu_vaccine "Flu vaccine"), reducing the number of lineages targeted by the vaccine from four to three.[[581]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-WHOflu2023-582)[[582]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-UMN2023-583)

triples.sentence: Hospital visits fell.[[562]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-563)
triples.statement: During the pandemic, hospital visits decreased.

triples.sentence: Visits for heart attack symptoms declined by 38% in the US and 40% in Spain.[[563]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-564)
triples.statement: In the US and Spain, visits for heart attack symptoms declined by 38% and 40% respectively.

triples.sentence: The pandemic impacted [mental health](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mental_health "Mental health"),[[568]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-569)[[569]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Stix_2021-570) increasing [anxiety](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anxiety "Anxiety"), depression, and [post-traumatic stress disorder](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Post-traumatic_stress_disorder "Post-traumatic stress disorder"), affecting healthcare workers, patients and quarantined individuals.[[570]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-571)[[571]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Santomauro_2021-572)
triples.statement: The pandemic impacted mental health, leading to increased anxiety, depression, and post-traumatic stress disorder among healthcare workers, patients, and quarantined individuals.

triples.sentence: This formed the beginning of the 2022–2023 paediatric care crisis and what some experts termed a "[tripledemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tripledemic "Tripledemic")" of seasonal influenza, [respiratory syncytial virus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Respiratory_syncytial_virus "Respiratory syncytial virus") (RSV), and SARS-CoV-2 throughout North America.[[573]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-574)[[574]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-575)
triples.statement: This surge marked the start of the 2022–2023 pediatric care crisis, which some experts called a "tripledemic" of seasonal flu, RSV, and SARS-CoV-2 in North America.

triples.sentence: In the United Kingdom, paediatric infections also began to spike beyond pre-pandemic levels, albeit with different illnesses, such as [Group A streptococcal infection](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Group_A_streptococcal_infection "Group A streptococcal infection") and resultant [scarlet fever](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scarlet_fever "Scarlet fever").[[575]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-576)[[576]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-United_Kingdom-577)
triples.statement: In the UK, pediatric infections, including Group A streptococcal infection and scarlet fever, also spiked above pre-pandemic levels.

section_body:
Main article: [Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the environment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_on_the_environment "Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the environment")

[![Image 57](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Pollutant_Drops_in_wuhan_china_due_to_virus.png/500px-Pollutant_Drops_in_wuhan_china_due_to_virus.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Pollutant_Drops_in_wuhan_china_due_to_virus.png)

Images from the [NASA Earth Observatory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NASA_Earth_Observatory "NASA Earth Observatory") show a stark drop in pollution in [Wuhan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wuhan "Wuhan"), when comparing [NO 2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nitrogen_dioxide "Nitrogen dioxide") levels in early 2019 (top) and early 2020 (bottom).[[583]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-584)

The pandemic and the reaction to it positively affected the [environment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_environment "Natural environment") and [climate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Climate "Climate") as a result of reduced human activity. During the "[anthropause](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anthropause "Anthropause")", fossil fuel use decreased, resource consumption declined, and waste disposal improved, generating less pollution.[[584]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-:9-585)[Planned air travel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic#Transportation "Economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic") and vehicle transportation declined. In China, [lockdowns](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_lockdown_in_Hubei "COVID-19 lockdown in Hubei") and other measures resulted in a 26% decrease in coal consumption, and a 50% reduction in nitrogen oxides emissions.[[584]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-:9-585)[[585]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-586)[[586]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-587)

In 2020, a worldwide study on mammalian wildlife responses to human presence during COVID lockdowns found complex patterns of animal behaviour. Carnivores were generally less active when humans were around, while herbivores in developed areas were more active. Among other findings, this suggested that herbivores may view humans as a shield against predators, highlighting the importance of location and human presence history in understanding wildlife responses to changes in human activity in a given area.[[587]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-588)

A [wide variety](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_animals_that_can_get_SARS-CoV-2 "List of animals that can get SARS-CoV-2") of largely mammalian species, both captive and wild, have been shown to be susceptible to SARS-CoV-2, with some encountering a particularly high degree of fatal outcomes.[[588]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-589) In particular, both [farmed and wild mink](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SARS-CoV-2_in_mink "SARS-CoV-2 in mink") have developed highly symptomatic and severe COVID-19 infections, with a mortality rate as high as 35–55% according to one study.[[589]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Frontiers_Spread-590)[[590]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-591)[White-tailed deer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SARS-CoV-2_in_white-tailed_deer "SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer"), on the other hand, have largely avoided severe outcomes but have effectively become [natural reservoirs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_reservoir "Natural reservoir") of the virus, with large numbers of free-ranging deer infected throughout the US and Canada, including approximately 80% of [Iowa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iowa "Iowa")'s wild deer herd.[[591]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-592)[[592]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Nature_April-593) An August 2023 study appeared to confirm the status of white-tailed deer as a disease reservoir, noting that the viral evolution of SARS-CoV-2 in deer occurs at triple the rate of its evolution in humans and that infection rates remained high, even in areas rarely frequented by humans.[[593]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Triple_Evolution-594)

triples.sentence: In China, [lockdowns](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_lockdown_in_Hubei "COVID-19 lockdown in Hubei") and other measures resulted in a 26% decrease in coal consumption, and a 50% reduction in nitrogen oxides emissions.[[584]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-:9-585)[[585]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-586)[[586]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-587)
triples.statement: In China, lockdowns and other measures led to a 26% decrease in coal consumption and a 50% reduction in nitrogen oxides emissions.

triples.sentence: Among other findings, this suggested that herbivores may view humans as a shield against predators, highlighting the importance of location and human presence history in understanding wildlife responses to changes in human activity in a given area.[[587]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-588)
triples.statement: Among other findings, it was suggested that herbivores might perceive humans as a shield against predators, which underscores the significance of location and historical human presence in understanding wildlife reactions to changes in human activity.

triples.sentence: [White-tailed deer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SARS-CoV-2_in_white-tailed_deer "SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer"), on the other hand, have largely avoided severe outcomes but have effectively become [natural reservoirs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_reservoir "Natural reservoir") of the virus, with large numbers of free-ranging deer infected throughout the US and Canada, including approximately 80% of [Iowa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iowa "Iowa")'s wild deer herd.[[591]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-592)[[592]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Nature_April-593)
triples.statement: White-tailed deer have mostly avoided severe outcomes from the virus but have become natural reservoirs, with many free-ranging deer infected across the US and Canada, including about 80% of Iowa's wild deer herd.

section_body:
Main article: [Xenophobia and racism related to the COVID-19 pandemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xenophobia_and_racism_related_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic "Xenophobia and racism related to the COVID-19 pandemic")

[![Image 58](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Memorial_Day_2020_-_San_Francisco_Under_Quarantine_%2849935630543%29.jpg/250px-Memorial_Day_2020_-_San_Francisco_Under_Quarantine_%2849935630543%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Memorial_Day_2020_-_San_Francisco_Under_Quarantine_(49935630543).jpg)

A socially distanced homeless encampment in San Francisco, California, in May 2020[[594]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-595)

Heightened prejudice, [xenophobia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xenophobia "Xenophobia"), and racism toward people of [Chinese and East Asian descent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sinophobe "Sinophobe") were documented around the world.[[595]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AutoDW-251-596)[[596]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-zogcf-597) Reports from February 2020, when most confirmed cases were confined to China, cited racist sentiments about Chinese people 'deserving' the virus.[[597]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-bangkokpost1854094-598)[[598]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-psychologytoday202002-599)[[599]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200201telegraph-600) Individuals of Asian descent in Europe and North America reported increasing instances of racially motivated abuse and assaults as a result of the pandemic.[[600]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-NYT_Racism-601)[[601]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-05O7n-602)[[602]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-NYT_April_Racism-603) US president [Donald Trump](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump") was criticised for referring to SARS-CoV-2 as the "Chinese Virus" and "Kung Flu", terms which were condemned as being racist and xenophobic.[[603]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-trumpnyt-604)[[604]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200320BI-605)[[605]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-MNCw4-606)

[Age-based discrimination](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ageism "Ageism") against older adults increased during the pandemic. This was attributed to their perceived vulnerability and subsequent physical and social isolation measures, which, coupled with their reduced social activity, increased dependency on others. Similarly, limited digital literacy left the elderly more vulnerable to isolation, depression, and loneliness.[[606]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-607)

In a correspondence published in _[The Lancet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_Lancet "The Lancet")_ in 2021, German epidemiologist Günter Kampf described the harmful effects of "inappropriate stigmatisation of unvaccinated people, who include our patients, colleagues, and other fellow citizens", noting the evidence that vaccinated individuals play a large role in transmission.[[607]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-608) American bioethicist Arthur Caplan responded to Kampf, writing "Criticising [the unvaccinated] who... wind up in hospitals and morgues in huge numbers, put stress on finite resources, and prolong the pandemic... is not stigmatising, it is deserved moral condemnation".[[608]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-609)

In January 2022, [Amnesty International](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amnesty_International "Amnesty International") urged [Italy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Italy "COVID-19 pandemic in Italy") to change their anti-COVID-19 restrictions to avoid discrimination against unvaccinated people, saying that "the government must continue to ensure that the entire population can enjoy its fundamental rights". The restrictions included mandatory vaccination over the age of 50, and mandatory vaccination to use public transport.[[609]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-610)

triples.sentence: Reports from February 2020, when most confirmed cases were confined to China, cited racist sentiments about Chinese people 'deserving' the virus.[[597]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-bangkokpost1854094-598)[[598]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-psychologytoday202002-599)[[599]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200201telegraph-600)
triples.statement: In February 2020, when most cases were in China, reports cited racist views that Chinese people 'deserved' the virus.

triples.sentence: US president [Donald Trump](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump") was criticised for referring to SARS-CoV-2 as the "Chinese Virus" and "Kung Flu", terms which were condemned as being racist and xenophobic.[[603]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-trumpnyt-604)[[604]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200320BI-605)[[605]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-MNCw4-606)
triples.statement: US President Donald Trump faced criticism for calling SARS-CoV-2 the "Chinese Virus" and "Kung Flu," terms that were condemned as racist and xenophobic.

section_body:
[![Image 59](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Wee_Annie%2C_Kempock_Street%2C_face_mask.jpg/250px-Wee_Annie%2C_Kempock_Street%2C_face_mask.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Wee_Annie,_Kempock_Street,_face_mask.jpg)

The "Wee Annie" statue in [Gourock](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gourock,_Scotland "Gourock, Scotland"), Scotland, was given a face mask during the pandemic.

The pandemic triggered massive changes in behaviour, from increased Internet commerce to cultural changes in the workplace. Online retailers in the US posted $791.70 billion in sales in 2020, an increase of 32.4% from $598.02 billion the year before.[[610]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-DDCV1ECMR-611) Home delivery orders increased, while indoor restaurant dining shut down due to lockdown orders or low sales.[[611]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Fo18zrty783-612)[[612]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Fo18zrty784-613) Hackers, [cybercriminals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cybercriminal "Cybercriminal") and scammers took advantage of the changes to launch new online attacks.[[613]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Fo18zrty787-614)

Education in some countries temporarily shifted from physical attendance to video conferencing.[[614]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Fo18zrty790-615) Massive layoffs shrank the airline, travel, hospitality, and other industries.[[615]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Fo18zrty6966-616)[[616]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Fo18zrty9999-617) Despite most corporations implementing measures to address COVID-19 in the workplace, a poll from [Catalyst](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Catalyst_(nonprofit_organization) "Catalyst (nonprofit organization)") found that as many as 68% of employees around the world felt that these policies were only performative and "not genuine".[[617]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-618)

The pandemic led to a surge in [remote work](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Remote_work "Remote work"). According to a [Gallup poll](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gallup_poll "Gallup poll"), only 4% of US employees were fully remote before the pandemic, compared to 43% in May 2020. Among white collar workers, that shift was more pronounced, with 6% increasing to 65% in the same period.[[618]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-The_New_York_Times_2022-619) That trend continued in later stages of the pandemic, with many workers choosing to remain remote even after workplaces reopened.[[619]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Mitchell_2022-620)[[620]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Kagubare_2023-621) Many Nordic, European, and Asian companies increased their recruitment of international remote workers even as the pandemic waned, partially to save on labour costs.[[621]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-ComputerWeekly.com_2023-622)[[622]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Braesemann_Stephany_Teutloff_K%C3%A4ssi_2022_p=e0274630-623) This also led to a talent drain in the global south and in remote areas in the global north.[[622]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Braesemann_Stephany_Teutloff_K%C3%A4ssi_2022_p=e0274630-623)[[623]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-EuropeanStingWEF2023-624) High cost of living and dense urban areas also lost office real estate value due to remote worker exodus.[[624]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Economist2022Jan-625) By May 2023, due to increasing layoffs and concerns over productivity, some white collar workplaces in the US had resorted to performance review penalties and indirect incentives (e.g. donations to charity) to encourage workers to return to the office.[[625]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Peck_2023-626)

triples.sentence: Online retailers in the US posted $791.70 billion in sales in 2020, an increase of 32.4% from $598.02 billion the year before.[[610]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-DDCV1ECMR-611)
triples.statement: In 2020, US online retailers' sales reached $791.70 billion, a 32.4% increase from the $598.02 billion recorded the previous year.

triples.sentence: Home delivery orders increased, while indoor restaurant dining shut down due to lockdown orders or low sales.[[611]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Fo18zrty783-612)[[612]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Fo18zrty784-613)
triples.statement: Home delivery orders increased, while indoor restaurant dining ceased due to lockdown orders or low sales.

triples.sentence: Many Nordic, European, and Asian companies increased their recruitment of international remote workers even as the pandemic waned, partially to save on labour costs.[[621]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-ComputerWeekly.com_2023-622)[[622]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Braesemann_Stephany_Teutloff_K%C3%A4ssi_2022_p=e0274630-623)
triples.statement: As the pandemic waned, many Nordic, European, and Asian companies increased hiring of international remote workers, partly to reduce labor costs.

triples.sentence: This also led to a talent drain in the global south and in remote areas in the global north.[[622]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Braesemann_Stephany_Teutloff_K%C3%A4ssi_2022_p=e0274630-623)[[623]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-EuropeanStingWEF2023-624)
triples.statement: This trend also caused a talent drain in the global south and in remote areas of the global north.

section_body: A 2021 study noted that the COVID-19 pandemic had increased interest in epidemics and infectious diseases among both historians and the general public. Prior to the pandemic, these topics were usually overlooked by "general" history and only received attention in the [history of medicine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_medicine "History of medicine").[[626]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-627) Many comparisons were made between the COVID-19 and [1918 influenza pandemics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1918_influenza_pandemic "1918 influenza pandemic"),[[627]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-628)[[628]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-629) including the development of anti-mask movements,[[629]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-630)[[630]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-631) the widespread promotion of misinformation[[631]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-632)[[632]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-633) and the impact of [socioeconomic disparities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_determinants_of_health "Social determinants of health").[[633]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-634)

triples.sentence: A 2021 study noted that the COVID-19 pandemic had increased interest in epidemics and infectious diseases among both historians and the general public.[[626]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-627)
triples.statement: A 2021 study noted that the COVID-19 pandemic increased interest in epidemics and infectious diseases among historians and the general public.

triples.sentence: Prior to the pandemic, these topics were usually overlooked by "general" history and only received attention in the [history of medicine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_medicine "History of medicine").[[626]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-627)
triples.statement: Before the pandemic, topics like epidemics were typically overlooked in general history and only received attention within the history of medicine.

section_body:
Main article: [Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on religion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_on_religion "Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on religion")

[![Image 60: Two men in masks, wearing mitres and red vestments, stand in front of an altar. Altar servers, deacons, and priests in the background similarly wear masks.](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Solenidade_de_Pentecostes_2020%2C_m%C3%A1scaras.png/250px-Solenidade_de_Pentecostes_2020%2C_m%C3%A1scaras.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Solenidade_de_Pentecostes_2020,_m%C3%A1scaras.png)

[Jorge Ortiga](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jorge_Ortiga "Jorge Ortiga"), [Archbishop of Braga](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Archdiocese_of_Braga "Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Braga"), Portugal, wearing a protective mask during [Pentecost](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pentecost "Pentecost") Mass in May 2020

In some areas, religious groups exacerbated the spread of the virus, through large gatherings and the dissemination of misinformation.[[634]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-635)[[635]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-636)[[636]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-637) Some religious leaders decried what they saw as violations of religious freedom.[[637]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-638) In other cases, religious identity was a beneficial factor for health, increasing compliance with public health measures and protecting against the negative effects of isolation on mental wellbeing.[[638]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-639)[[639]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-640)[[640]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-641)

triples.sentence: In some areas, religious groups exacerbated the spread of the virus, through large gatherings and the dissemination of misinformation.[[634]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-635)[[635]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-636)[[636]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-637)
triples.statement: In some areas, religious groups worsened the spread of the virus through large gatherings and the dissemination of misinformation.

section_body:
Further information: [Media coverage of the COVID-19 pandemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Media_coverage_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic "Media coverage of the COVID-19 pandemic"), [Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on social media](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_on_social_media "Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on social media"), and [Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on journalism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_on_journalism "Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on journalism")

Some news organisations removed their online paywalls for some or all of their pandemic-related articles and posts.[[641]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-642) Many scientific publishers provided pandemic-related journal articles to the public free of charge as part of the National Institutes of Health's COVID-19 Public Health Emergency Initiative.[[642]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-643)[[643]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-644) According to one estimate from researchers at the University of Rome, 89.5% of COVID-19-related papers were open access, compared to an average of 48.8% for the ten most deadly human diseases.[[644]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-645) The share of papers published on preprint servers prior to peer review increased dramatically.[[645]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-646)

During the pandemic, [Web GIS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_GIS "Web GIS") technology was leveraged to provide up to date visualisations of data related to the pandemic with the public.[[646]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Juergens2020-647) Employing this technology, the [Johns Hopkins University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Johns_Hopkins_University "Johns Hopkins University") COVID-19 [dashboard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dashboard_(computing) "Dashboard (computing)") served as the first global visualisation of COVID-19 data, which established it as the default method for government agencies to dissemeniate relevant spatial information.[[647]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Everts2020-648)[[648]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Adams2025-649) These dashboards were described by Jonathan Everts as "the most striking cultural artefact of the current coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic",[[647]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Everts2020-648) and during the pandemic every state government in the United States maintained one.[[649]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Adams2023-650)

triples.sentence: During the pandemic, [Web GIS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_GIS "Web GIS") technology was leveraged to provide up to date visualisations of data related to the pandemic with the public.[[646]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Juergens2020-647)
triples.statement: During the pandemic, Web GIS technology was used to provide the public with up-to-date visualizations of data related to the pandemic.

triples.sentence: Employing this technology, the [Johns Hopkins University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Johns_Hopkins_University "Johns Hopkins University") COVID-19 [dashboard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dashboard_(computing) "Dashboard (computing)") served as the first global visualisation of COVID-19 data, which established it as the default method for government agencies to dissemeniate relevant spatial information.[[647]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Everts2020-648)[[648]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Adams2025-649)
triples.statement: The Johns Hopkins University COVID-19 dashboard was the first global visualization of COVID-19 data, establishing it as the default method for government agencies to disseminate relevant spatial information.

triples.sentence: These dashboards were described by Jonathan Everts as "the most striking cultural artefact of the current coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic",[[647]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Everts2020-648) and during the pandemic every state government in the United States maintained one.[[649]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Adams2023-650)
triples.statement: Jonathan Everts described these dashboards as "the most striking cultural artefact of the current coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic," and every state government in the United States maintained one during the pandemic.

section_body:
Main article: [COVID-19 misinformation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_misinformation "COVID-19 misinformation")

[Misinformation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Misinformation "Misinformation") and [conspiracy theories](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conspiracy_theory "Conspiracy theory") about the pandemic have been widespread; they travel through [mass media](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Media_coverage_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic "Media coverage of the COVID-19 pandemic"), [social media](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_on_social_media#Misinformation "Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on social media") and text messaging.[[650]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-FTTextMsg-651) In March 2020, WHO declared an "[infodemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infodemic "Infodemic")" of incorrect information.[[651]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Lowy-652)[Cognitive biases](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_bias "Cognitive bias"), such as [confirmation bias](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Confirmation_bias "Confirmation bias"), are linked to conspiracy beliefs, including [COVID-19 vaccine hesitancy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_vaccine_hesitancy "COVID-19 vaccine hesitancy").[[652]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-653)

triples.sentence: [Misinformation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Misinformation "Misinformation") and [conspiracy theories](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conspiracy_theory "Conspiracy theory") about the pandemic have been widespread; they travel through [mass media](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Media_coverage_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic "Media coverage of the COVID-19 pandemic"), [social media](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_on_social_media#Misinformation "Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on social media") and text messaging.[[650]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-FTTextMsg-651)
triples.statement: Widespread misinformation and conspiracy theories about the pandemic were disseminated through mass media, social media, and text messaging.

section_body:
Further information: [COVID-19 pandemic in popular culture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_popular_culture "COVID-19 pandemic in popular culture")

The COVID-19 pandemic had a major impact on popular culture. It was included in the narratives of ongoing pre-pandemic television series and become a central narrative in new ones, with mixed results.[[653]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-654) Writing for _[The New York Times](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_New\_York\_Times "The New York Times")_ about the then-upcoming [BBC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BBC "BBC") sitcom _[Pandemonium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Here\_We\_Go\_(TV\_series)#Pilot "Here We Go (TV series)")_ on 16 December 2020, [David Segal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Segal_(journalist) "David Segal (journalist)") asked, "Are we ready to laugh about Covid-19? Or rather, is there anything amusing, or recognizable in a humorous way, about life during a plague, with all of its indignities and setbacks, not to mention its rituals and rules".[[654]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-655)

The pandemic had driven some people to seek peaceful [escapism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Escapism "Escapism") in media, while others were drawn towards fictional pandemics (e.g. [zombie apocalypses](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zombie_apocalypse "Zombie apocalypse")) as an alternate form of escapism.[[655]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-656) Common themes have included [contagion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contagious_disease "Contagious disease"), [isolation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isolation_(health_care) "Isolation (health care)") and loss of [control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_(psychology) "Control (psychology)").[[656]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-657) Many drew comparisons to the fictional film _[Contagion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contagion\_(2011\_film) "Contagion (2011 film)")_ (2011),[[657]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-658)[[658]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-659) praising its accuracies while noting some differences,[[659]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-660) such as the lack of an orderly vaccine rollout.[[660]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-661)[[661]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-662)

As people turned to music to relieve emotions evoked by the pandemic, [Spotify](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spotify "Spotify") listenership showed that classical, [ambient](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ambient_music "Ambient music") and [children's](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Children%27s_music "Children's music") genres grew, while pop, [country](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Country_music "Country music") and dance remained relatively stable.[[662]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-663)

triples.sentence: Many drew comparisons to the fictional film _[Contagion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contagion\_(2011\_film) "Contagion (2011 film)")_ (2011),[[657]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-658)[[658]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-659) praising its accuracies while noting some differences,[[659]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-660) such as the lack of an orderly vaccine rollout.[[660]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-661)[[661]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-662)
triples.statement: Many people compared the pandemic to the 2011 film Contagion, praising its accuracy but also noting differences, such as the absence of an orderly vaccine rollout in the movie.

section_body:
Main article: [Endemic COVID-19](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Endemic_COVID-19 "Endemic COVID-19")

A March 2022 review declared a transition to endemic status to be "inevitable".[[663]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-664) In June 2022, an article in _[Human Genomics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human\_Genome\_Organisation "Human Genome Organisation")_ said that the pandemic was still "raging", but that "now is the time to explore the transition from the pandemic to the endemic phase".[[664]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-665) Another review that month predicted that the virus that causes COVID-19 would become the fifth endemic seasonal coronavirus, alongside four other [human coronaviruses](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HCoV "HCoV").[[665]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-666)

A February 2023 review of the four [common cold](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Common_cold "Common cold") coronaviruses concluded that the virus would become seasonal and, like the common cold, cause less severe disease for most people.[[666]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-667) Another 2023 review stated that the transition to endemic COVID-19 may take years or decades.[[667]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-668)

On 5 May 2023, the WHO declared that the pandemic was no longer a [public health emergency of international concern](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_health_emergency_of_international_concern "Public health emergency of international concern").[[668]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-669) This led several media outlets to incorrectly report that this meant the pandemic was "over". The WHO commented to [Full Fact](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Full_Fact "Full Fact") that it was unlikely to declare the pandemic over "in the near future" and mentioned [cholera](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cholera "Cholera"), which it considers to have been a [pandemic since 1961](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seventh_cholera_pandemic "Seventh cholera pandemic") (i.e., continuously for the last 64 years).[[669]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-ff-670) The WHO does not have an official category for pandemics or make declarations of when pandemics start or end.[[4]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-reuters-4)[[262]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-guardian-263)[[670]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-671)[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-timemarch2024-13)

In June 2023, [Hans Kluge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hans_Kluge "Hans Kluge"), director of the WHO in Europe, commented that "While the international public health emergency may have ended, the pandemic certainly has not". The WHO in Europe launched a transition plan to manage the public health response to COVID-19 in the coming years and prepare for possible future emergencies.[[671]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-kluge-672)

Epidemics and pandemics usually end when the disease becomes [endemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Endemic_COVID-19 "Endemic COVID-19"), and when the disease becomes "an accepted, manageable part of normal life in a given society".[[15]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-charters2021-15) As of March 2024, there was no widely agreed definition of when a disease is or is not a pandemic, though efforts at a formal definition were underway. Experts asked by _[Time](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time\_(magazine) "Time (magazine)")_ that month noted that COVID-19 continued to circulate and cause disease, but expressed uncertainty as to whether it should still be described as a pandemic.[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-timemarch2024-13)

triples.sentence: The WHO does not have an official category for pandemics or make declarations of when pandemics start or end.[[4]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-reuters-4)[[262]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-guardian-263)[[670]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-671)[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-timemarch2024-13)
triples.statement: The WHO does not have an official category for pandemics and does not declare when they begin or end.

triples.sentence: The WHO in Europe launched a transition plan to manage the public health response to COVID-19 in the coming years and prepare for possible future emergencies.[[671]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-kluge-672)
triples.statement: The WHO in Europe launched a transition plan to manage the public health response to COVID-19 and prepare for future emergencies.

section_body:
Despite strong economic rebounds following the initial lockdowns in early 2020, towards the latter phases of the pandemic, many countries began to experience long-term economic effects. Several countries saw high [inflation rates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inflation_rate "Inflation rate") which had global impacts, particularly in developing countries.[[672]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-673) Some economic impacts such as [supply chain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supply_chain "Supply chain") and trade operations were seen as more permanent as the pandemic exposed major weaknesses in these systems.[[673]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-674)

In Australia, the pandemic caused an increase in [occupational burnout](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Occupational_burnout "Occupational burnout") in 2022.[[674]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-675)

During the pandemic, a large percentage of workers in Canada came to prefer working from home, which had an impact on the traditional work model. Some corporations made efforts to force workers to return to work on-site, while some embraced the idea.[[675]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-676)

triples.sentence: Some economic impacts such as [supply chain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supply_chain "Supply chain") and trade operations were seen as more permanent as the pandemic exposed major weaknesses in these systems.[[673]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-674)
triples.statement: The pandemic exposed major weaknesses in supply chain and trade systems, leading some economic impacts to be viewed as more permanent.

section_body: There was a "travel boom" causing air travel to recover at rates faster than anticipated, and the aviation industry became profitable in 2023 for the first time since 2019, before the pandemic.[[676]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-677) However, economic issues meant some predicted that the boom would begin to slow down.[[677]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-678) Business travel on airlines was still below pre-pandemic levels and is predicted not to recover.[[678]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-679)

triples.sentence: Business travel on airlines was still below pre-pandemic levels and is predicted not to recover.[[678]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-679)
triples.statement: Business air travel remained below pre-pandemic levels and is predicted not to recover.

section_body: An increase in excess deaths from underlying causes not related to COVID-19 has been largely blamed on systematic issues causing delays in health care and screening during the pandemic, which has resulted in an increase of non-COVID-19 related deaths.[[679]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-680)

triples.sentence: An increase in excess deaths from underlying causes not related to COVID-19 has been largely blamed on systematic issues causing delays in health care and screening during the pandemic, which has resulted in an increase of non-COVID-19 related deaths.[[679]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-680)
triples.statement: An increase in excess deaths from non-COVID-19 causes has been largely blamed on systematic issues that caused delays in health care and screening during the pandemic.

section_body:
During the pandemic, millions of children missed out on vaccinations as countries focused efforts on combating COVID-19. Efforts were made to increase vaccination rates among children in [low-income countries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Low-income_countries "Low-income countries"). These efforts were successful in increasing vaccination rates for some diseases, though the UN noted that post-pandemic [measles vaccinations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Measles_vaccination "Measles vaccination") were still falling behind.[[680]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-681)

Some of the decrease in immunisation was driven by an increase in mistrust of public health officials. This was seen in both low-income and high-income countries. Several [African countries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/African_countries "African countries") saw a decline in vaccinations due to misinformation around the pandemic flowing into other areas.[[681]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-682) Immunisation rates have yet to recover in the United States[[682]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-683) and the United Kingdom.[[683]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-684)

triples.sentence: Immunisation rates have yet to recover in the United States[[682]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-683) and the United Kingdom.[[683]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-684)
triples.statement: Immunisation rates have not yet returned to previous levels in the United States and the United Kingdom.
